Title:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7 Security Technical Implementation Guide
Description:This Security Technical Implementation Guide is published as a tool to improve the security of Department of Defense (DoD) information systems. The requirements are derived from the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) 800-53 and related documents. Comments or proposed revisions to this document should be sent via email to the following address: disa.stig_spt@mail.mil.

Target Platforms:

    • The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that the SSH daemon does not allow authentication using known hosts authentication. - (CCE-80372-6) - Pass
  • SRG-OS-000074-GPOS-00042
    • The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that the SSH daemon is configured to only use the SSHv2 protocol. - (CCE-27320-1) - Pass
  • SRG-OS-000250-GPOS-00093
    • The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that the SSH daemon is configured to only use Message Authentication Codes (MACs) employing FIPS 140-2 approved cryptographic hash algorithms. - (CCE-27455-5) - Pass
  • SRG-OS-000480-GPOS-00227
    • The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that the SSH public host key files have mode 0644 or less permissive. - (CCE-27311-0) - Pass
  • SRG-OS-000480-GPOS-00227
    • The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that the SSH private host key files have mode 0600 or less permissive. - (CCE-27485-2) - Pass
  • SRG-OS-000364-GPOS-00151
    • The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that the SSH daemon does not permit Generic Security Service Application Program Interface (GSSAPI) authentication unless needed. - Pass
  • SRG-OS-000364-GPOS-00151
    • The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that the SSH daemon does not permit Kerberos authentication unless needed. - (CCE-80221-5) - Pass
  • SRG-OS-000480-GPOS-00227
    • The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that the SSH daemon performs strict mode checking of home directory configuration files. - (CCE-80222-3) - Pass
  • SRG-OS-000480-GPOS-00227
    • The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that the SSH daemon uses privilege separation. - (CCE-80223-1) - Pass
  • SRG-OS-000480-GPOS-00227
    • The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that the SSH daemon does not allow compression or only allows compression after successful authentication. - Pass
  • SRG-OS-000480-GPOS-00227
    • The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must display the date and time of the last successful account logon upon logon. - Fail
  • SRG-OS-000480-GPOS-00227
    • The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must not contain .shosts files. - Pass
  • SRG-OS-000480-GPOS-00227
    • The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must not contain shosts.equiv files. - Pass
  • SRG-OS-000480-GPOS-00227
    • The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must not forward Internet Protocol version 4 (IPv4) source-routed packets. - (CCE-27434-0) - Fail
  • SRG-OS-000480-GPOS-00227
    • The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must not forward Internet Protocol version 4 (IPv4) source-routed packets by default. - (CCE-80162-1) - Fail
  • SRG-OS-000480-GPOS-00227
    • The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must not respond to Internet Protocol version 4 (IPv4) Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) echoes sent to a broadcast address. - (CCE-80165-4) - Fail
  • SRG-OS-000480-GPOS-00227
    • The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must prevent Internet Protocol version 4 (IPv4) Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) redirect messages from being accepted. - (CCE-80163-9) - Fail
  • SRG-OS-000480-GPOS-00227
    • The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must ignore Internet Protocol version 4 (IPv4) Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) redirect messages. - (CCE-80158-9) - Fail
  • SRG-OS-000480-GPOS-00227
    • The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must not allow interfaces to perform Internet Protocol version 4 (IPv4) Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) redirects by default. - (CCE-80156-3) - Fail
  • SRG-OS-000480-GPOS-00227
    • The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must not send Internet Protocol version 4 (IPv4) Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) redirects. - (CCE-80156-3) - Fail
  • SRG-OS-000480-GPOS-00227
    • The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must not have a File Transfer Protocol (FTP) server package installed unless needed. - Pass
  • SRG-OS-000480-GPOS-00227
    • The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must not have the Trivial File Transfer Protocol (TFTP) server package installed if not required for operational support. - (CCE-80213-2) - Pass
  • SRG-OS-000480-GPOS-00227
    • The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that remote X connections are disabled except to fulfill documented and validated mission requirements. - (CCE-80226-4) - Pass
  • SRG-OS-000480-GPOS-00227
    • The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must not have a graphical display manager installed unless approved. - (CCE-27218-7) - Pass
  • SRG-OS-000480-GPOS-00227
    • The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must not be performing packet forwarding unless the system is a router. - (CCE-80157-1) - Fail
  • SRG-OS-000480-GPOS-00227
    • SNMP community strings on the Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be changed from the default. - (CCE-27386-2) - Pass
  • SRG-OS-000480-GPOS-00227
    • The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must not forward IPv6 source-routed packets. - (CCE-80179-5) - Fail
  • SRG-OS-000375-GPOS-00160
    • The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must have the required packages for multifactor authentication installed. - Fail
  • SRG-OS-000375-GPOS-00160
    • The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must implement multifactor authentication for access to privileged accounts via pluggable authentication modules (PAM). - (CCE-80437-7) - Fail
  • SRG-OS-000375-GPOS-00160
    • The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must implement certificate status checking for PKI authentication. - Fail
  • SRG-OS-000480-GPOS-00227
    • The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that the cryptographic hash of system files and commands matches vendor values. - (CCE-27157-7) - Pass
  • SRG-OS-000480-GPOS-00227
    • The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must restrict privilege elevation to authorized personnel. - Pass
  • SRG-OS-000480-GPOS-00227
    • The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must use the invoking user's password for privilege escalation when using "sudo". - Fail
  • SRG-OS-000373-GPOS-00156
    • The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must require re-authentication when using the "sudo" command. - Error

Detailed Results

The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must display the Standard Mandatory DoD Notice and Consent Banner before granting local or remote access to the system via a graphical user logon.

Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204393r603261_rule
Result:Pass
Version:RHEL-07-010030
Identities:CCE-26970-4
V-71859
SV-86483
CCI-000048 (NIST SP 800-53: AC-8 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AC-8.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-8 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-8 a)
Description: Display of a standardized and approved use notification before granting access to the operating system ensures privacy and security notification verbiage used is consistent with applicable federal laws, Executive Orders, directives, policies, regulations, standards, and guidance.

System use notifications are required only for access via logon interfaces with human users and are not required when such human interfaces do not exist.

The banner must be formatted in accordance with applicable DoD policy. Use the following verbiage for operating systems that can accommodate banners of 1300 characters:

"You are accessing a U.S. Government (USG) Information System (IS) that is provided for USG-authorized use only.

By using this IS (which includes any device attached to this IS), you consent to the following conditions:

-The USG routinely intercepts and monitors communications on this IS for purposes including, but not limited to, penetration testing, COMSEC monitoring, network operations and defense, personnel misconduct (PM), law enforcement (LE), and counterintelligence (CI) investigations.

-At any time, the USG may inspect and seize data stored on this IS.

-Communications using, or data stored on, this IS are not private, are subject to routine monitoring, interception, and search, and may be disclosed or used for any USG-authorized purpose.

-This IS includes security measures (e.g., authentication and access controls) to protect USG interests--not for your personal benefit or privacy.

-Notwithstanding the above, using this IS does not constitute consent to PM, LE or CI investigative searching or monitoring of the content of privileged communications, or work product, related to personal representation or services by attorneys, psychotherapists, or clergy, and their assistants. Such communications and work product are private and confidential. See User Agreement for details."


Satisfies: SRG-OS-000023-GPOS-00006, SRG-OS-000024-GPOS-00007, SRG-OS-000228-GPOS-00088 false
Fix Text:Configure the operating system to display the Standard Mandatory DoD Notice and Consent Banner before granting access to the system.

Note: If the system does not have GNOME installed, this requirement is Not Applicable.

Create a database to contain the system-wide graphical user logon settings (if it does not already exist) with the following command:

# touch /etc/dconf/db/local.d/01-banner-message

Add the following line to the [org/gnome/login-screen] section of the "/etc/dconf/db/local.d/01-banner-message":

[org/gnome/login-screen]
banner-message-enable=true

Update the system databases:

# dconf update

Users must log out and back in again before the system-wide settings take effect.
Severity:medium
Weight:10.0
Reference:
Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Publisher:DISA
Type:DPMS Target
Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Identifier:2899
Definitions:
Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:922
Result:true
Title:Enable GNOME3 Login Warning Banner
Description:Enable the GNOME3 Login warning banner.
Class:compliance
Tests:
  • true (One or more child checks must be true.)
    • false (All child checks must be true.)
      • false (GUI banner is enabled)
      • true (One or more child checks must be true.)
        • true (dconf user profile exists)
        • true (All child checks must be true.) (negated)
          • false (package dconf is installed)
    • true (All child checks must be true.) (negated)
      • false (package dconf is installed)
Tests:
Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:925 (textfilecontent54_test)
Result:false
Title:GUI banner is enabled
Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
Check:Result is based on check existence only.
Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2720 (textfilecontent54_object)
Object Requirements:
  • behavior requirements:
    • recurse_direction = down
    • max_depth = 1
  • path must be equal to '/etc/dconf/db'
  • filename must match the pattern '^[0-9].*$'
  • pattern must match the pattern '^\[org/gnome/login-screen\]([^\n]*\n+)+?banner-message-enable\s*=\s*true\s*$'
  • instance must be equal to '1'
Include Items If:
  • path matches the pattern '^/etc/dconf/db/[^/]+\.d/?$'
Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:1022 (textfilecontent54_test)
Result:true
Title:dconf user profile exists
Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
Check:Result is based on check existence only.
Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2792 (textfilecontent54_object)
Object Requirements:
  • filepath must be equal to '/etc/dconf/profile/user'
  • pattern must match the pattern '^user-db:user\nsystem-db:local$'
  • instance must be equal to '1'
Collected Item/State Result:
[ not evaluated ]
  • filepath equals '/etc/dconf/profile/user'
  • path equals '/etc/dconf/profile'
  • filename equals 'user'
  • pattern equals '^user-db:user\nsystem-db:local$'
  • instance equals '1'
  • text equals 'user-db:user system-db:local'
  • line equals 'user-db:user system-db:local'
  • subexpression does not exist
Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:1252 (rpminfo_test)
Result:false
Title:package dconf is installed
Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
Check:Result is based on check existence only.
Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2983 (rpminfo_object)
Object Requirements:
  • name must be equal to 'dconf'
Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must enable a user session lock until that user re-establishes access using established identification and authentication procedures.

Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204396r603261_rule
Result:Pass
Version:RHEL-07-010060
Identities:CCE-80112-6
SV-86515
V-71891
CCI-000056 (NIST SP 800-53: AC-11 b; NIST SP 800-53A: AC-11.1 (iii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-11 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-11 b)
Description: A session lock is a temporary action taken when a user stops work and moves away from the immediate physical vicinity of the information system but does not want to log out because of the temporary nature of the absence.

The session lock is implemented at the point where session activity can be determined.

Regardless of where the session lock is determined and implemented, once invoked, the session lock must remain in place until the user reauthenticates. No other activity aside from reauthentication must unlock the system.

Satisfies: SRG-OS-000028-GPOS-00009, SRG-OS-000030-GPOS-00011 false
Fix Text:Configure the operating system to enable a user's session lock until that user re-establishes access using established identification and authentication procedures.

Create a database to contain the system-wide screensaver settings (if it does not already exist) with the following example:

# touch /etc/dconf/db/local.d/00-screensaver

Edit the "[org/gnome/desktop/screensaver]" section of the database file and add or update the following lines:

# Set this to true to lock the screen when the screensaver activates
lock-enabled=true

Update the system databases:

# dconf update

Users must log out and back in again before the system-wide settings take effect.
Severity:medium
Weight:10.0
Reference:
Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Publisher:DISA
Type:DPMS Target
Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Identifier:2899

Result:true
Title:Enable GNOME3 Screensaver Lock After Idle Period
Description:Idle activation of the screen lock should be enabled.
Class:compliance
Tests:
  • true (One or more child checks must be true.)
    • false (All child checks must be true.)
      • false (screensaver lock is enabled)
      • true (One or more child checks must be true.)
        • true (dconf user profile exists)
        • true (All child checks must be true.) (negated)
          • false (package dconf is installed)
    • true (All child checks must be true.) (negated)
      • false (package dconf is installed)
Tests:
Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:989 (textfilecontent54_test)

Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
Check:Result is based on check existence only.

The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must uniquely identify and must authenticate users using multifactor authentication via a graphical user logon.

Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204397r603261_rule
Result:Pass
Version:RHEL-07-010061
Identities:V-77819
SV-92515
CCI-001948 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-2 (11))
CCI-001953 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-2 (12); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: IA-2 (12))
CCI-001954 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-2 (12); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: IA-2 (12))
Description: To assure accountability and prevent unauthenticated access, users must be identified and authenticated to prevent potential misuse and compromise of the system.

Multifactor solutions that require devices separate from information systems gaining access include, for example, hardware tokens providing time-based or challenge-response authenticators and smart cards such as the U.S. Government Personal Identity Verification card and the DoD Common Access Card.

Satisfies: SRG-OS-000375-GPOS-00161,SRG-OS-000375-GPOS-00162 false
Fix Text:Configure the operating system to uniquely identify and authenticate users using multifactor authentication via a graphical user logon.

Note: If the system does not have GNOME installed, this requirement is Not Applicable.

Create a database to contain the system-wide screensaver settings (if it does not already exist) with the following command:

Note: The example is using the database local for the system, so if the system is using another database in "/etc/dconf/profile/user", the file should be created under the appropriate subdirectory.

# touch /etc/dconf/db/local.d/00-defaults

Edit "[org/gnome/login-screen]" and add or update the following line:
enable-smartcard-authentication=true

Update the system databases:
# dconf update
Severity:medium
Weight:10.0
Reference:
Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Publisher:DISA
Type:DPMS Target
Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Identifier:2899
Definitions:
Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:92515
Result:true
Title:Smartcard authentication enabled for graphical user logon.
Description:The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must uniquely identify and must authenticate users using multifactor authentication via a graphical user logon.
Class:compliance
Tests:
  • true (One or more child checks must be true.)
    • false (All child checks must be true.)
      • false (check for enable-smartcard-authentication set to true)
      • true (check for enable-smartcard-authentication set to false) (negated)
      • true (One or more child checks must be true.)
        • true (dconf user profile exists)
        • true (All child checks must be true.) (negated)
          • false (package dconf is installed)
    • true (All child checks must be true.) (negated)
      • false (package dconf is installed)

The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must initiate a screensaver after a 15-minute period of inactivity for graphical user interfaces.

Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204398r603261_rule
Result:Pass
Version:RHEL-07-010070
Identities:CCE-80110-0
V-71893
SV-86517
CCI-000057 (NIST SP 800-53: AC-11 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AC-11.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-11 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-11 a)
Description: A session time-out lock is a temporary action taken when a user stops work and moves away from the immediate physical vicinity of the information system but does not log out because of the temporary nature of the absence. Rather than relying on the user to manually lock their operating system session prior to vacating the vicinity, operating systems need to be able to identify when a user's session has idled and take action to initiate the session lock.

The session lock is implemented at the point where session activity can be determined and/or controlled. false
Fix Text:Configure the operating system to initiate a screensaver after a 15-minute period of inactivity for graphical user interfaces.

Create a database to contain the system-wide screensaver settings (if it does not already exist) with the following command:

# touch /etc/dconf/db/local.d/00-screensaver

Edit /etc/dconf/db/local.d/00-screensaver and add or update the following lines:

[org/gnome/desktop/session]
# Set the lock time out to 900 seconds before the session is considered idle
idle-delay=uint32 900

You must include the "uint32" along with the integer key values as shown.

Update the system databases:

# dconf update

Users must log out and back in again before the system-wide settings take effect.
Severity:medium
Weight:10.0
Reference:
Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Publisher:DISA
Type:DPMS Target
Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Identifier:2899
Definitions:
Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:981
Result:true
Title:Configure the GNOME3 GUI Screen locking
Description:The allowed period of inactivity before the screensaver is activated.
Class:compliance
Tests:
  • true (One or more child checks must be true.)
    • false (All child checks must be true.)
      • false (screensaver idle delay is configured)
      • true (One or more child checks must be true.)
        • true (dconf user profile exists)
        • true (All child checks must be true.) (negated)
          • false (package dconf is installed)
    • true (All child checks must be true.) (negated)
      • false (package dconf is installed)
Tests:
Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:982 (textfilecontent54_test)
Result:false
Title:screensaver idle delay is configured
Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2761 (textfilecontent54_object)
Object Requirements:
  • behavior requirements:
    • recurse_direction = down
    • max_depth = 1
  • path must be equal to '/etc/dconf/db/'
  • filename must match the pattern '^[0-9].*$'
  • pattern must match the pattern '^\[org/gnome/desktop/session\](?:[^\n]*\n+)+?idle-delay\s*=\s*uint32[\s]+([0-9]*)'
  • instance must be equal to '1'
State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:2764 (textfilecontent54_state)
State Requirements:
  • for check = 'all', subexpression, all of the following must be true:
    • subexpression must be less than or equal to '900'
Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:1022 (textfilecontent54_test)
Result:true
Title:dconf user profile exists
Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
Check:Result is based on check existence only.
Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2792 (textfilecontent54_object)
Object Requirements:
  • filepath must be equal to '/etc/dconf/profile/user'
  • pattern must match the pattern '^user-db:user\nsystem-db:local$'
  • instance must be equal to '1'
Collected Item/State Result:
[ not evaluated ]
  • filepath equals '/etc/dconf/profile/user'
  • path equals '/etc/dconf/profile'
  • filename equals 'user'
  • pattern equals '^user-db:user\nsystem-db:local$'
  • instance equals '1'
  • text equals 'user-db:user system-db:local'
  • line equals 'user-db:user system-db:local'
  • subexpression does not exist
Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:1252 (rpminfo_test)
Result:false
Title:package dconf is installed
Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
Check:Result is based on check existence only.
Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2983 (rpminfo_object)
Object Requirements:
  • name must be equal to 'dconf'
Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must prevent a user from overriding the screensaver lock-delay setting for the graphical user interface.

Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204399r603261_rule
Result:Pass
Version:RHEL-07-010081
Identities:CCE-80371-8
V-73155
SV-87807
CCI-000057 (NIST SP 800-53: AC-11 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AC-11.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-11 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-11 a)
Description: A session time-out lock is a temporary action taken when a user stops work and moves away from the immediate physical vicinity of the information system but does not log out because of the temporary nature of the absence. Rather than relying on the user to manually lock their operating system session prior to vacating the vicinity, operating systems need to be able to identify when a user's session has idled and take action to initiate the session lock.

The session lock is implemented at the point where session activity can be determined and/or controlled. false
Fix Text:Configure the operating system to prevent a user from overriding a screensaver lock after a 15-minute period of inactivity for graphical user interfaces.

Create a database to contain the system-wide screensaver settings (if it does not already exist) with the following command:

Note: The example below is using the database "local" for the system, so if the system is using another database in "/etc/dconf/profile/user", the file should be created under the appropriate subdirectory.

# touch /etc/dconf/db/local.d/locks/session

Add the setting to lock the screensaver lock delay:

/org/gnome/desktop/screensaver/lock-delay
Severity:medium
Weight:10.0
Reference:
Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Publisher:DISA
Type:DPMS Target
Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
Identifier:2899
Definitions:
Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:999
Result:true
Title:Gnome lock-delay setting lock
Description:Determines if the databases containing the lock-delay setting also have the setting locked.
Class:compliance
Tests:
  • true (One or more child checks must be true.)
    • false (All child checks must be true.)
      • false (lock-delay configuration is present)
      • false (lock-delay lock exists)
      • true (all lock-delay entries are locked)
    • true (All child checks must be true.) (negated)
      • false (package dconf is installed)
Tests:

Result:false
Title:lock-delay configuration is present
Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
Check:Result is based on check existence only.
Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2765 (textfilecontent54_object)
Object Requirements:
  • behavior requirements:
    • recurse_direction = down
    • max_depth = 1
  • path must be equal to '/etc/dconf/db/'
  • filename must match the pattern '^[0-9].*$'
  • pattern must match the pattern '^\[org/gnome/desktop/screensaver\]([^\n]*\n+)+?lock-delay\s*=\s*uint32\s+[0-5]\s*$'
  • instance must be equal to '1'
Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:8780702 (textfilecontent54_test)
Result:false
Title:lock-delay lock exists
Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
Check:Result is based on check existence only.
Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:8780700 (textfilecontent54_object)
Object Requirements:
  • behavior requirements:
    • recurse_direction = down
    • max_depth = 1
  • for path, at least one of the following must be true:
    • path must be equal to '/locks'
  • filename must match the pattern '^.*$'
  • pattern must match the pattern '^/org/gnome/desktop/screensaver/lock-delay$'
  • instance must be equal to '1'

Result:true
Title:all lock-delay entries are locked
Check Existence:No collected items may exist.
Check:Result is based on check existence only.

    The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must initiate a session lock for the screensaver after a period of inactivity for graphical user interfaces.

    Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204402r603261_rule
    Result:Pass
    Version:RHEL-07-010100
    Identities:CCE-80111-8
    V-71899
    SV-86523
    CCI-000057 (NIST SP 800-53: AC-11 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AC-11.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-11 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-11 a)
    Description: A session time-out lock is a temporary action taken when a user stops work and moves away from the immediate physical vicinity of the information system but does not log out because of the temporary nature of the absence. Rather than relying on the user to manually lock their operating system session prior to vacating the vicinity, operating systems need to be able to identify when a user's session has idled and take action to initiate the session lock.

    The session lock is implemented at the point where session activity can be determined and/or controlled. false
    Fix Text:Configure the operating system to initiate a session lock after a 15-minute period of inactivity for graphical user interfaces.

    Create a database to contain the system-wide screensaver settings (if it does not already exist) with the following command:

    # touch /etc/dconf/db/local.d/00-screensaver

    Add the setting to enable screensaver locking after 15 minutes of inactivity:

    [org/gnome/desktop/screensaver]

    idle-activation-enabled=true

    Update the system databases:

    # dconf update

    Users must log out and back in again before the system-wide settings take effect.
    Severity:medium
    Weight:10.0

    The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must prevent a user from overriding the screensaver idle-activation-enabled setting for the graphical user interface.

    Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204403r603261_rule
    Result:Pass
    Version:RHEL-07-010101
    Identities:V-78997
    SV-93703
    CCI-000057 (NIST SP 800-53: AC-11 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AC-11.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-11 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-11 a)
    Description: A session lock is a temporary action taken when a user stops work and moves away from the immediate physical vicinity of the information system but does not want to log out because of the temporary nature of the absence.

    The session lock is implemented at the point where session activity can be determined.

    The ability to enable/disable a session lock is given to the user by default. Disabling the user's ability to disengage the graphical user interface session lock provides the assurance that all sessions will lock after the specified period of time. false
    Fix Text:Configure the operating system to prevent a user from overriding a screensaver lock after a 15-minute period of inactivity for graphical user interfaces.

    Create a database to contain the system-wide screensaver settings (if it does not already exist) with the following command:

    Note: The example below is using the database "local" for the system, so if the system is using another database in "/etc/dconf/profile/user", the file should be created under the appropriate subdirectory.

    # touch /etc/dconf/db/local.d/locks/session

    Add the setting to lock the screensaver idle-activation-enabled setting:

    /org/gnome/desktop/screensaver/idle-activation-enabled
    Severity:medium
    Weight:10.0
    Reference:
    Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
    Publisher:DISA
    Type:DPMS Target
    Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
    Identifier:2899
    Definitions:
    Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:93703
    Result:true
    Title:The operating system must prevent a user from overriding the screensaver idle-activation-enabled setting for the graphical user interface.
    Description:A session lock is a temporary action taken when a user stops work and moves away from the immediate physical vicinity of the information system but does not want to log out because of the temporary nature of the absence. The session lock is implemented at the point where session activity can be determined. The ability to enable/disable a session lock is given to the user by default. Disabling the user's ability to disengage the graphical user interface session lock provides the assurance that all sessions will lock after the specified period of time.
    Class:compliance
    Tests:
    • true (One or more child checks must be true.)
      • false (All child checks must be true.)
        • false (idle-activation-enabled configuration is present)
        • false (idle-activation-enabled lock exists)
        • true (all idle-activation-enabled entries are locked)
      • true (All child checks must be true.) (negated)
        • false (package dconf is installed)

    Check:Result is based on check existence only.
    Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:9370300 (textfilecontent54_object)
    Object Requirements:
    • behavior requirements:
      • recurse_direction = down
      • max_depth = 1
    • path must be equal to '/etc/dconf/db/'
    • filename must match the pattern '^[0-9].*$'
    • pattern must match the pattern '^\[org/gnome/desktop/screensaver\]([^\n]*\n+)+?idle-activation-enabled\s*=\s*(?:true|false)\s*$'
    • instance must be equal to '1'
    Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
    Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:9370302 (textfilecontent54_test)

      • path must be equal to '/locks'

    • instance must be equal to '1'

    Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:9370301 (textfilecontent54_test)

      The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must initiate a session lock for graphical user interfaces when the screensaver is activated.

      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204404r603261_rule
      Result:Pass
      Version:RHEL-07-010110
      Identities:CCE-80370-0
      V-71901
      SV-86525
      CCI-000057 (NIST SP 800-53: AC-11 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AC-11.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-11 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-11 a)
      Description: A session time-out lock is a temporary action taken when a user stops work and moves away from the immediate physical vicinity of the information system but does not log out because of the temporary nature of the absence. Rather than relying on the user to manually lock their operating system session prior to vacating the vicinity, operating systems need to be able to identify when a user's session has idled and take action to initiate the session lock.

      The session lock is implemented at the point where session activity can be determined and/or controlled. false
      Fix Text:Configure the operating system to initiate a session lock for graphical user interfaces when a screensaver is activated.

      Create a database to contain the system-wide screensaver settings (if it does not already exist) with the following command:

      # touch /etc/dconf/db/local.d/00-screensaver

      Add the setting to enable session locking when a screensaver is activated:

      [org/gnome/desktop/screensaver]
      lock-delay=uint32 5

      The "uint32" must be included along with the integer key values as shown.

      Update the system databases:

      # dconf update

      Users must log out and back in again before the system-wide settings take effect.
      Severity:medium
      Weight:10.0
      Reference:

      The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that /etc/pam.d/passwd implements /etc/pam.d/system-auth when changing passwords.

      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204405r603261_rule
      Result:Pass
      Version:RHEL-07-010118
      Identities:SV-95715
      V-81003
      CCI-000192 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (a); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (a))
      Description: Pluggable authentication modules (PAM) allow for a modular approach to integrating authentication methods. PAM operates in a top-down processing model and if the modules are not listed in the correct order, an important security function could be bypassed if stack entries are not centralized. false
      Fix Text:Configure PAM to utilize /etc/pam.d/system-auth when changing passwords.

      Add the following line to "/etc/pam.d/passwd" (or modify the line to have the required value):

      password substack system-auth
      Severity:medium
      Weight:10.0
      Reference:
      Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Publisher:DISA
      Type:DPMS Target
      Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Identifier:2899
      Definitions:
      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:95715
      Result:true
      Title:Verify /etc/pam.d/system-auth is included in /etc/pam.d/passwd
      Description:/etc/pam.d/system-auth is included in /etc/pam.d/passwd.
      Class:compliance
      Tests:
      • true (All child checks must be true.)
        • true (/etc/pam.d/system-auth is included in /etc/pam.d/passwd.)
      Tests:
      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:9571500 (textfilecontent54_test)
      Result:true
      Title:/etc/pam.d/system-auth is included in /etc/pam.d/passwd.
      Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
      Check:Result is based on check existence only.
      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:9571500 (textfilecontent54_object)
      Object Requirements:
      • path must be equal to '/etc/pam.d'
      • filename must be equal to 'passwd'
      • pattern must match the pattern '^[\s]*password[ \t]+substack[ \t]+system-auth\s*$'
      • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
      Collected Item/State Result:
      [ not evaluated ]
      • filepath equals '/etc/pam.d/passwd'
      • path equals '/etc/pam.d'
      • filename equals 'passwd'
      • pattern equals '^[\s]*password[ \t]+substack[ \t]+system-auth\s*$'
      • instance equals '1'
      • text equals 'password substack system-auth'
      • line equals 'password substack system-auth'
      • subexpression does not exist

      The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that when passwords are changed or new passwords are established, pwquality must be used.

      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204406r603261_rule
      Result:Pass
      Version:RHEL-07-010119
      Identities:CCE-27160-1
      SV-87811
      V-73159
      CCI-000192 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (a); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (a))
      Description: Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks. "pwquality" enforces complex password construction configuration and has the ability to limit brute-force attacks on the system. false
      Fix Text:Configure the operating system to use "pwquality" to enforce password complexity rules.

      Add the following line to "/etc/pam.d/system-auth" (or modify the line to have the required value):

      password required pam_pwquality.so retry=3

      Note: The value of "retry" should be between "1" and "3".
      Severity:medium
      Weight:10.0
      Reference:
      Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Publisher:DISA
      Type:DPMS Target
      Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Identifier:2899
      Definitions:
      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:481
      Result:true
      Title:Set Password retry Requirements
      Description:The password retry should meet minimum requirements
      Class:compliance
      Tests:
      • true (One or more child checks must be true.)
        • true (check the configuration of /etc/pam.d/system-auth)
      Tests:
      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:483 (textfilecontent54_test)
      Result:true
      Title:check the configuration of /etc/pam.d/system-auth
      Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
      Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2371 (textfilecontent54_object)
      Object Requirements:
      • filepath must be equal to '/etc/pam.d/system-auth'
      • pattern must match the pattern '^[ \t]*password[ \t]+(?:(?:required)|(?:requisite))[ \t]+pam_pwquality\.so(?:[ \t]+|(?:[ \t][^#\r\f\n]+[ \t]+))retry=([0-9]+)(?:\s|$)'
      • instance must be equal to '1'
      State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:2370 (textfilecontent54_state)
      State Requirements:
      • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must match the pattern '^[123]$'
      Collected Item/State Result:
      [ true ]
      • filepath equals '/etc/pam.d/system-auth'
      • path equals '/etc/pam.d'
      • filename equals 'system-auth'
      • pattern equals '^[ \t]*password[ \t]+(?:(?:required)|(?:requisite))[ \t]+pam_pwquality\.so(?:[ \t]+|(?:[ \t][^#\r\f\n]+[ \t]+))retry=([0-9]+)(?:\s|$)'
      • instance equals '1'
      • text equals 'password requisite pam_pwquality.so try_first_pass local_users_only retry=3 '
      • line equals 'password requisite pam_pwquality.so try_first_pass local_users_only retry=3 '
      • subexpression equals '3'

      The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that when passwords are changed or new passwords are established, the new password must contain at least one upper-case character.

      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204407r603261_rule
      Result:Fail
      Version:RHEL-07-010120
      Identities:CCE-27200-5
      SV-86527
      V-71903
      CCI-000192 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (a); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (a))
      Description: Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks.

      Password complexity is one factor of several that determines how long it takes to crack a password. The more complex the password, the greater the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised. false
      Fix Text:Configure the operating system to enforce password complexity by requiring that at least one upper-case character be used by setting the "ucredit" option.

      Add the following line to "/etc/security/pwquality.conf" (or modify the line to have the required value):

      ucredit = -1
      Severity:medium
      Weight:10.0
      Reference:
      Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Publisher:DISA
      Type:DPMS Target
      Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Identifier:2899
      Definitions:
      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:484
      Result:false
      Title:Set Password ucredit Requirements
      Description:The password ucredit should meet minimum requirements
      Class:compliance
      Tests:
      • false (All child checks must be true.)
        • false (check the configuration of /etc/security/pwquality.conf)
        • true (All child checks must be true.)
          • true (check the configuration of /etc/pam.d/system-auth)
      Tests:
      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:485 (textfilecontent54_test)
      Result:false
      Title:check the configuration of /etc/security/pwquality.conf
      Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
      Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2372 (textfilecontent54_object)
      Object Requirements:
      • filepath must be equal to '/etc/security/pwquality.conf'
      • pattern must match the pattern '^ucredit[\s]*=[\s]*(-?\d+)(?:[\s]|$)'
      • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
      State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:2373 (textfilecontent54_state)
      State Requirements:
      • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', instance must be equal to '1'
      • for check = 'all', subexpression, the following must be true:
        • subexpression must be less than or equal to '-1'
      Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:480 (textfilecontent54_test)
      Result:true
      Title:check the configuration of /etc/pam.d/system-auth
      Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
      Check:Result is based on check existence only.
      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2368 (textfilecontent54_object)
      Object Requirements:
      • filepath must be equal to '/etc/pam.d/system-auth'
      • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*password\s+(?:(?:required)|(?:requisite))\s+pam_pwquality\.so.*$'
      • instance must be equal to '1'
      Collected Item/State Result:
      [ not evaluated ]
      • filepath equals '/etc/pam.d/system-auth'
      • path equals '/etc/pam.d'
      • filename equals 'system-auth'
      • pattern equals '^\s*password\s+(?:(?:required)|(?:requisite))\s+pam_pwquality\.so.*$'
      • instance equals '1'
      • text equals ' password requisite pam_pwquality.so try_first_pass local_users_only retry=3 authtok_type='
      • line equals ' password requisite pam_pwquality.so try_first_pass local_users_only retry=3 authtok_type='
      • subexpression does not exist

      The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that when passwords are changed or new passwords are established, the new password must contain at least one lower-case character.

      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204408r603261_rule
      Result:Fail
      Version:RHEL-07-010130
      Identities:CCE-27345-8
      SV-86529
      V-71905
      CCI-000193 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (a); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (a))
      Description: Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks.

      Password complexity is one factor of several that determines how long it takes to crack a password. The more complex the password, the greater the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised. false
      Fix Text:Configure the system to require at least one lower-case character when creating or changing a password.

      Add or modify the following line
      in "/etc/security/pwquality.conf":

      lcredit = -1
      Severity:medium
      Weight:10.0
      Reference:
      Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Publisher:DISA

        • true (All child checks must be true.)
          • true (check the configuration of /etc/pam.d/system-auth)

      The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that when passwords are changed a minimum of eight of the total number of characters must be changed.

      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204411r603261_rule
      Result:Fail
      Version:RHEL-07-010160
      Identities:CCE-26631-2
      V-71911
      SV-86535
      CCI-000195 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (b); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (b))
      Description: Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks.

      Password complexity is one factor of several that determines how long it takes to crack a password. The more complex the password, the greater the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised. false
      Fix Text:Configure the operating system to require the change of at least eight of the total number of characters when passwords are changed by setting the "difok" option.

      Add the following line to "/etc/security/pwquality.conf" (or modify the line to have the required value):

      difok = 8

      The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that when passwords are changed a minimum of four character classes must be changed.

      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204412r603261_rule
      Result:Fail
      Version:RHEL-07-010170
      Identities:CCE-27115-5
      V-71913
      SV-86537

      Description: Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks.

      The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that when passwords are changed the number of repeating consecutive characters must not be more than three characters.

      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204413r603261_rule
      Result:Fail
      Version:RHEL-07-010180
      Identities:CCE-27333-4
      SV-86539
      V-71915
      CCI-000195 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (b); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (b))
      Description: Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks.

      Password complexity is one factor of several that determines how long it takes to crack a password. The more complex the password, the greater the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised. false
      Fix Text:Configure the operating system to require the change of the number of repeating consecutive characters when passwords are changed by setting the "maxrepeat" option.

      Add the following line to "/etc/security/pwquality.conf conf" (or modify the line to have the required value):

      maxrepeat = 3
      Severity:medium
      Weight:10.0
      Reference:
      Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Publisher:DISA
      Type:DPMS Target
      Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Identifier:2899
      Definitions:
      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:472
      Result:false
      Title:Set Password maxrepeat Requirements
      Description:The password maxrepeat should meet minimum requirements using pam_pwquality
      Class:compliance
      Tests:
      • false (All child checks must be true.)
        • false (check the configuration of /etc/security/pwquality.conf)
        • true (All child checks must be true.)
          • true (check the configuration of /etc/pam.d/system-auth)
      Tests:
      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:473 (textfilecontent54_test)
      Result:false
      Title:check the configuration of /etc/security/pwquality.conf
      Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
      Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2360 (textfilecontent54_object)
      Object Requirements:
      • filepath must be equal to '/etc/security/pwquality.conf'
      • pattern must match the pattern '^maxrepeat[\s]*=[\s]*(-?\d+)(?:[\s]|$)'
      • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
      State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:2361 (textfilecontent54_state)
      State Requirements:
      • for check = 'all', subexpression, the following must be true:
        • subexpression must be less than or equal to '3'
      Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:480 (textfilecontent54_test)
      Result:true
      Title:check the configuration of /etc/pam.d/system-auth
      Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
      Check:Result is based on check existence only.
      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2368 (textfilecontent54_object)
      Object Requirements:
      • filepath must be equal to '/etc/pam.d/system-auth'
      • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*password\s+(?:(?:required)|(?:requisite))\s+pam_pwquality\.so.*$'
      • instance must be equal to '1'
      Collected Item/State Result:
      [ not evaluated ]
      • filepath equals '/etc/pam.d/system-auth'
      • path equals '/etc/pam.d'
      • filename equals 'system-auth'
      • pattern equals '^\s*password\s+(?:(?:required)|(?:requisite))\s+pam_pwquality\.so.*$'
      • instance equals '1'
      • text equals ' password requisite pam_pwquality.so try_first_pass local_users_only retry=3 authtok_type='
      • line equals ' password requisite pam_pwquality.so try_first_pass local_users_only retry=3 authtok_type='
      • subexpression does not exist

      The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that when passwords are changed the number of repeating characters of the same character class must not be more than four characters.

      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204414r809186_rule
      Result:Fail
      Version:RHEL-07-010190
      Identities:CCE-27512-3
      SV-86541
      V-71917
      CCI-000195 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (b); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (b))
      Description: Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks.

      Password complexity is one factor of several that determines how long it takes to crack a password. The more complex the password, the greater the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised. false
      Fix Text:Configure the operating system to require the change of the number of repeating characters of the same character class when passwords are changed by setting the "maxclassrepeat" option.

      Add the following line to "/etc/security/pwquality.conf" conf (or modify the line to have the required value):

      maxclassrepeat = 4
      Severity:medium
      Weight:10.0
      Reference:
      Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Publisher:DISA
      Type:DPMS Target
      Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Identifier:2899
      Definitions:
      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:470
      Result:false
      Title:The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that when passwords are changed the number of repeating characters of the same character class must not be more than four characters.
      Description:Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks. Password complexity is one factor of several that determines how long it takes to crack a password. The more complex the password, the greater the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised.
      Class:compliance
      Tests:
      • false (All child checks must be true.)
        • false (check the configuration of /etc/security/pwquality.conf)
      Tests:
      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:471 (textfilecontent54_test)
      Result:false
      Title:check the configuration of /etc/security/pwquality.conf
      Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
      Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
      State Operator:All item-state comparisons must be true.
      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2358 (textfilecontent54_object)
      Object Requirements:
      • filepath must be equal to '/etc/security/pwquality.conf'
      • pattern must match the pattern '^maxclassrepeat[\s]*=[\s]*(-?\d+)(?:[\s]|$)'
      • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
      State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:2359 (textfilecontent54_state)
      State Requirements:
      • for check = 'all', subexpression, the following must be true:
        • subexpression must be less than or equal to '4'
      State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:47000 (textfilecontent54_state)
      State Requirements:
      • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be greater than '0'
      Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

      The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that the PAM system service is configured to store only encrypted representations of passwords.

      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204415r603261_rule
      Result:Pass
      Version:RHEL-07-010200
      Identities:CCE-27104-9
      V-71919
      SV-86543
      CCI-000196 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (c); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (c))
      Description: Passwords need to be protected at all times, and encryption is the standard method for protecting passwords. If passwords are not encrypted, they can be plainly read (i.e., clear text) and easily compromised. Passwords encrypted with a weak algorithm are no more protected than if they are kept in plain text. false
      Fix Text:Configure the operating system to store only SHA512 encrypted representations of passwords.

      Add the following line in "/etc/pam.d/system-auth":
      pam_unix.so sha512 shadow try_first_pass use_authtok

      Add the following line in "/etc/pam.d/password-auth":
      pam_unix.so sha512 shadow try_first_pass use_authtok

      Note: Manual changes to the listed files may be overwritten by the "authconfig" program. The "authconfig" program should not be used to update the configurations listed in this requirement.
      Severity:medium
      Weight:10.0
      Reference:
      Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Publisher:DISA
      Type:DPMS Target
      Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Identifier:2899
      Definitions:
      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:1367
      Result:true
      Title:Set Password Hashing Algorithm in /etc/pam.d/system-auth
      Description:The password hashing algorithm should be set correctly in /etc/pam.d/system-auth.
      Class:compliance
      Tests:
      • true (All child checks must be true.)
        • true (check /etc/pam.d/system-auth for correct settings)
        • true (check /etc/pam.d/system-auth for md5, sha256, blowfish, or bigcrypt in the password require|sufficient pam_unix.so lines) (negated)
        • true (check /etc/pam.d/password-auth for correct settings)
        • true (check /etc/pam.d/password-auth for md5, sha256, blowfish, or bigcrypt in the password require|sufficient pam_unix.so lines) (negated)

      • path must be equal to '/etc/pam.d'
      • filename must be equal to 'system-auth'
      • pattern must match the pattern '^[\s]*password[ \t]+(?:(?:required)|(?:sufficient))[ \t]+pam_unix\.so(.*)$'
      • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'

      The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured to use the shadow file to store only encrypted representations of passwords.

      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204416r603261_rule
      Result:Pass
      Version:RHEL-07-010210
      Identities:CCE-27124-7
      V-71921
      SV-86545
      CCI-000196 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (c); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (c))
      Description: Passwords need to be protected at all times, and encryption is the standard method for protecting passwords. If passwords are not encrypted, they can be plainly read (i.e., clear text) and easily compromised. Passwords encrypted with a weak algorithm are no more protected than if they are kept in plain text. false
      Fix Text:Configure the operating system to store only SHA512 encrypted representations of passwords.

      Add or update the following line in "/etc/login.defs":

      ENCRYPT_METHOD SHA512
      Severity:medium
      Weight:10.0
      Reference:
      Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Publisher:DISA
      Type:DPMS Target
      Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Identifier:2899
      Definitions:
      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:1365
      Result:true
      Title:Set SHA512 Password Hashing Algorithm in /etc/login.defs
      Description:The password hashing algorithm should be set correctly in /etc/login.defs.
      Class:compliance
      Tests:
      • true (All child checks must be true.)
        • true (The value of ENCRYPT_METHOD should be set appropriately in /etc/login.defs)
      Tests:
      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:1366 (textfilecontent54_test)
      Result:true
      Title:The value of ENCRYPT_METHOD should be set appropriately in /etc/login.defs
      Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
      Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:3759 (textfilecontent54_object)
      Object Requirements:
      • filepath must be equal to '/etc/login.defs'
      • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*ENCRYPT_METHOD\s+(\w+)\s*$'
      • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
      State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:3056 (textfilecontent54_state)
      State Requirements:
      • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be equal to 'SHA512'

      [ true ]

      • path equals '/etc'

      • instance equals '1'
      • text equals 'ENCRYPT_METHOD SHA512 '
      • line equals 'ENCRYPT_METHOD SHA512 '
      • subexpression equals 'SHA512'

      The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that user and group account administration utilities are configured to store only encrypted representations of passwords.

      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204417r603261_rule
      Result:Pass
      Version:RHEL-07-010220
      Identities:CCE-27053-8
      V-71923
      SV-86547
      CCI-000196 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (c); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (c))
      Description: Passwords need to be protected at all times, and encryption is the standard method for protecting passwords. If passwords are not encrypted, they can be plainly read (i.e., clear text) and easily compromised. Passwords encrypted with a weak algorithm are no more protected than if they are kept in plain text. false
      Fix Text:Configure the operating system to store only SHA512 encrypted representations of passwords.

      Add or update the following line in "/etc/libuser.conf" in the [defaults] section:

      crypt_style = sha512
      Severity:medium
      Weight:10.0
      Reference:

      Publisher:DISA

        • true (The password hashing algorithm should be set correctly in /etc/libuser.conf)
      Tests:
      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:1364 (textfilecontent54_test)
      Result:true

      Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
      Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).

      The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that passwords for new users are restricted to a 24 hours/1 day minimum lifetime.

      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204418r603261_rule
      Result:Fail
      Version:RHEL-07-010230
      Identities:CCE-27002-5
      V-71925
      SV-86549
      CCI-000198 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (d); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (d))
      Description: Enforcing a minimum password lifetime helps to prevent repeated password changes to defeat the password reuse or history enforcement requirement. If users are allowed to immediately and continually change their password, the password could be repeatedly changed in a short period of time to defeat the organization's policy regarding password reuse. false
      Fix Text:Configure the operating system to enforce 24 hours/1 day as the minimum password lifetime.

      Add the following line in "/etc/login.defs" (or modify the line to have the required value):

      PASS_MIN_DAYS 1
      Severity:medium
      Weight:10.0
      Reference:
      Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Publisher:DISA
      Type:DPMS Target
      Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Identifier:2899
      Definitions:
      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:455
      Result:false
      Title:Set Password Expiration Parameters
      Description:The minimum password age policy should be set appropriately.
      Class:compliance
      Tests:
      • false (All child checks must be true.)
        • false (The value of PASS_MIN_DAYS should be set appropriately in /etc/login.defs)
      Tests:
      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:456 (textfilecontent54_test)
      Result:false
      Title:The value of PASS_MIN_DAYS should be set appropriately in /etc/login.defs
      Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
      Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:3730 (textfilecontent54_object)
      Object Requirements:
      • filepath must be equal to '/etc/login.defs'
      • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*PASS_MIN_DAYS\s+(\d+)\s*$'
      • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
      State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:2346 (textfilecontent54_state)
      State Requirements:
      • for check = 'all', subexpression, at least one of the following must be true:
        • subexpression must be greater than or equal to '1'
      Collected Item/State Result:
      [ false ]
      • filepath equals '/etc/login.defs'
      • path equals '/etc'
      • filename equals 'login.defs'
      • pattern equals '^\s*PASS_MIN_DAYS\s+(\d+)\s*$'
      • instance equals '1'
      • text equals 'PASS_MIN_DAYS 0'
      • line equals 'PASS_MIN_DAYS 0'
      • subexpression equals '0'
      Additional Information:Check requirement not met.
      subexpression

      The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that passwords are restricted to a 24 hours/1 day minimum lifetime.

      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204419r603261_rule
      Result:Fail
      Version:RHEL-07-010240
      Identities:SV-86551
      V-71927
      CCI-000198 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (d); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (d))
      Description: Enforcing a minimum password lifetime helps to prevent repeated password changes to defeat the password reuse or history enforcement requirement. If users are allowed to immediately and continually change their password, the password could be repeatedly changed in a short period of time to defeat the organization's policy regarding password reuse. false
      Fix Text:Configure non-compliant accounts to enforce a 24 hours/1 day minimum password lifetime:

      # chage -m 1 [user]
      Severity:medium
      Weight:10.0
      Reference:
      Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Publisher:DISA
      Type:DPMS Target
      Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Identifier:2899
      Definitions:
      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:86551
      Result:false
      Title:Passwords must be restricted to a 1 day minimum lifetime.
      Description:Passwords must be restricted to a 1 day minimum lifetime.
      Class:compliance
      Tests:
      • false (All child checks must be true.)
        • false (Passwords for interactive users must be restricted to a 1 day minimum lifetime.)
        • true (no shadow entries with null minimum password ages)
      Tests:

      Result:false
      Title:Passwords for interactive users must be restricted to a 1 day minimum lifetime.
      Check Existence:Zero or more collected items may exist.
      Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:8655100 (shadow_object)
      Object Requirements:
      • for username, at least one of the following must be true:
        • username must be equal to 'centos'
      State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:8655100 (shadow_state)
      State Requirements:
      • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', chg_allow must be greater than or equal to '1'
      Collected Item/State Result:
      [ false ]
      • username equals 'centos'
      • password equals [MASKED PASSWORD FIELD]
      • chg_lst equals '19301'
      • chg_allow equals '0'
      • chg_req equals '99999'
      • exp_warn equals '7'
      • exp_inact equals ''
      • exp_date equals ''
      • flag equals ''
      • encrypt_method equals ''
      Additional Information:Check requirement not met.
      chg_allow
      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:8655101 (textfilecontent54_test)
      Result:true
      Title:no shadow entries with null minimum password ages
      Check Existence:No collected items may exist.
      Check:Result is based on check existence only.

      • for pattern, at least one of the following must be true:
        • pattern must match the pattern '^centos:[^:]*:[^:]*::'
      • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'

      The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that passwords for new users are restricted to a 60-day maximum lifetime.

      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204420r603261_rule
      Result:Fail
      Version:RHEL-07-010250
      Identities:CCE-27051-2
      V-71929
      SV-86553
      CCI-000199 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (d); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (d))
      Description: Any password, no matter how complex, can eventually be cracked. Therefore, passwords need to be changed periodically. If the operating system does not limit the lifetime of passwords and force users to change their passwords, there is the risk that the operating system passwords could be compromised. false
      Fix Text:Configure the operating system to enforce a 60-day maximum password lifetime restriction.

      Add the following line in "/etc/login.defs" (or modify the line to have the required value):

      PASS_MAX_DAYS 60
      Severity:medium
      Weight:10.0
      Reference:
      Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Publisher:DISA
      Type:DPMS Target

      The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that existing passwords are restricted to a 60-day maximum lifetime.

      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204421r603261_rule
      Result:Fail
      Version:RHEL-07-010260
      Identities:V-71931
      SV-86555
      CCI-000199 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (d); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (d))
      Description: Any password, no matter how complex, can eventually be cracked. Therefore, passwords need to be changed periodically. If the operating system does not limit the lifetime of passwords and force users to change their passwords, there is the risk that the operating system passwords could be compromised. false
      Fix Text:Configure non-compliant accounts to enforce a 60-day maximum password lifetime restriction.

      # chage -M 60 [user]
      Severity:medium
      Weight:10.0
      Reference:
      Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Publisher:DISA
      Type:DPMS Target
      Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Identifier:2899
      Definitions:

      Class:compliance
      Tests:
      • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
        • false (All child checks must be true.)
          • false (Passwords for interactive users must be restricted to a 60-day maximum lifetime.)

          • true (no null max pw ages.)
        • false (interactive users exist.) (negated)

      The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that passwords are prohibited from reuse for a minimum of five generations.

      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204422r603261_rule
      Result:Fail
      Version:RHEL-07-010270
      Identities:CCE-26923-3
      V-71933
      SV-86557
      CCI-000200 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (e); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (e))
      Description: Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks. If the information system or application allows the user to consecutively reuse their password when that password has exceeded its defined lifetime, the end result is a password that is not changed per policy requirements. false
      Fix Text:Configure the operating system to prohibit password reuse for a minimum of five generations.

      Add the following line in "/etc/pam.d/system-auth" and "/etc/pam.d/password-auth" (or modify the line to have the required value):

      password requisite pam_pwhistory.so use_authtok remember=5 retry=3

      Note: Manual changes to the listed files may be overwritten by the "authconfig" program. The "authconfig" program should not be used to update the configurations listed in this requirement.
      Severity:medium
      Weight:10.0
      Reference:
      Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Publisher:DISA
      Type:DPMS Target
      Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Identifier:2899
      Definitions:
      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:486
      Result:false
      Title:Limit Password Reuse
      Description:The passwords to remember should be set correctly.
      Class:compliance
      Tests:
      • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
        • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
          • false (Test if remember attribute of pam_unix.so is set correctly in /etc/pam.d/system-auth)
          • false (Test if remember attribute of pam_pwhistory.so is set correctly in /etc/pam.d/system-auth)
        • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
          • false (Test if remember attribute of pam_unix.so is set correctly in /etc/pam.d/password-auth)
          • false (Test if remember attribute of pam_pwhistory.so is set correctly in /etc/pam.d/password-auth)
      Tests:
      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:487 (textfilecontent54_test)
      Result:false
      Title:Test if remember attribute of pam_unix.so is set correctly in /etc/pam.d/system-auth
      Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
      Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2374 (textfilecontent54_object)
      Object Requirements:
      • filepath must be equal to '/etc/pam.d/system-auth'
      • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*password\s+(?:(?:sufficient)|(?:required))\s+pam_unix\.so[^#\n\r]*remember=([0-9]*).*$'
      • instance must be equal to '1'
      State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:2375 (textfilecontent54_state)
      State Requirements:
      • for check = 'all', subexpression, the following must be true:
        • subexpression must be greater than or equal to '5'
      Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:488 (textfilecontent54_test)

      • instance must be equal to '1'

        • subexpression must be greater than or equal to '5'
