      The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that the root account must be the only account having unrestricted access to the system.

      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204462r603261_rule
      Result:Pass
      Version:RHEL-07-020310
      Identities:CCE-27175-9
      SV-86629
      V-72005
      CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
      Description: If an account other than root also has a User Identifier (UID) of "0", it has root authority, giving that account unrestricted access to the entire operating system. Multiple accounts with a UID of "0" afford an opportunity for potential intruders to guess a password for a privileged account. false
      Fix Text:Change the UID of any account on the system, other than root, that has a UID of "0".

      If the account is associated with system commands or applications, the UID should be changed to one greater than "0" but less than "1000". Otherwise, assign a UID of greater than "1000" that has not already been assigned.
      Severity:high
      Weight:10.0
      Reference:
      Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Publisher:DISA
      Type:DPMS Target
      Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Identifier:2899
      Definitions:
      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:457
      Result:true
      Title:UID 0 Belongs Only To Root
      Description:Only the root account should be assigned a user id of 0.
      Class:compliance
      Tests:
      • true (All child checks must be true.)
        • true (test that there are no accounts with UID 0 except root in the /etc/passwd file)
      Tests:
      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:458 (textfilecontent54_test)
      Result:true
      Title:test that there are no accounts with UID 0 except root in the /etc/passwd file
      Check Existence:No collected items may exist.
      Check:Result is based on check existence only.
      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2347 (textfilecontent54_object)
      Object Requirements:
      • filepath must be equal to '/etc/passwd'
      • pattern must match the pattern '^(?!root:)[^:]*:[^:]*:0'
      • instance must be equal to '1'

      The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that all local interactive user accounts, upon creation, are assigned a home directory.

      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204466r603261_rule
      Result:Pass
      Version:RHEL-07-020610
      Identities:CCE-80434-4
      V-72013
      SV-86637
      CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
      Description: If local interactive users are not assigned a valid home directory, there is no place for the storage and control of files they should own. false
      Fix Text:Configure the operating system to assign home directories to all new local interactive users by setting the "CREATE_HOME" parameter in "/etc/login.defs" to "yes" as follows.

      CREATE_HOME yes
      Severity:medium
      Weight:10.0
      Reference:
      Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Publisher:DISA
      Type:DPMS Target
      Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Identifier:2899
      Definitions:
      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:447
      Result:true
      Title:Ensure new users receive home directories
      Description:CREATE_HOME should be enabled
      Class:compliance
      Tests:
      • true (All child checks must be true.)
        • true (Check value of CREATE_HOME in /etc/login.defs)
      Tests:
      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:448 (textfilecontent54_test)
      Result:true
      Title:Check value of CREATE_HOME in /etc/login.defs
      Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
      Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2338 (textfilecontent54_object)
      Object Requirements:
      • filepath must be equal to '/etc/login.defs'
      • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*CREATE_HOME\s+(\S+)\s*$'
      • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
      State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:2338 (textfilecontent54_state)
      State Requirements:
      • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be equal to 'yes'
      Collected Item/State Result:
      [ true ]
      • filepath equals '/etc/login.defs'
      • path equals '/etc'
      • filename equals 'login.defs'
      • pattern equals '^\s*CREATE_HOME\s+(\S+)\s*$'
      • instance equals '1'
      • text equals 'CREATE_HOME yes '
      • line equals 'CREATE_HOME yes '
      • subexpression equals 'yes'

      The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that all local interactive users have a home directory assigned and defined in the /etc/passwd file.

      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204467r603826_rule
      Result:Pass
      Version:RHEL-07-020620
      Identities:V-72015
      SV-86639
      CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
      Description: If local interactive users are not assigned a valid home directory, there is no place for the storage and control of files they should own.

      In addition, if a local interactive user has a home directory defined that does not exist, the user may be given access to the / directory as the current working directory upon logon. This could create a Denial of Service because the user would not be able to access their logon configuration files, and it may give them visibility to system files they normally would not be able to access. false
      Fix Text:Create home directories to all local interactive users that currently do not have a home directory assigned. Use the following commands to create the user home directory assigned in "/etc/ passwd":

      Note: The example will be for the user smithj, who has a home directory of "/home/smithj", a UID of "smithj", and a Group Identifier (GID) of "users" assigned in "/etc/passwd".

      # mkdir /home/smithj
      # chown smithj /home/smithj
      # chgrp users /home/smithj
      # chmod 0750 /home/smithj
      Severity:medium
      Weight:10.0
      Reference:
      Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Publisher:DISA
      Type:DPMS Target
      Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Identifier:2899
      Definitions:
      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:86639
      Result:true
      Title:The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that all local interactive user home directories are defined in the /etc/passwd file.
      Description:The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that all local interactive user home directories are defined in the /etc/passwd file.
      Class:compliance
      Tests:
      • true (All child checks must be true.)
        • true (Verify all user home directories exist)
        • true (Verify root's home directory exists)
        • true (All child checks must be true.)
          • true (check for users without a home directory not defined)
          • true (check if root's home directory is not defined)
      Tests:

        • path must be equal to '/home/centos'

      The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must prevent files with the setuid and setgid bit set from being executed on file systems that are being imported via Network File System (NFS).

      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204482r603261_rule
      Result:Pass
      Version:RHEL-07-021020
      Identities:CCE-80240-5
      SV-86669
      V-72045
      CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
      Description: The "nosuid" mount option causes the system to not execute "setuid" and "setgid" files with owner privileges. This option must be used for mounting any file system not containing approved "setuid" and "setguid" files. Executing files from untrusted file systems increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access. false
      Fix Text:Configure the "/etc/fstab" to use the "nosuid" option on file systems that are being imported via NFS.
      Severity:medium
      Weight:10.0
      Reference:
      Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Publisher:DISA
      Type:DPMS Target
      Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Identifier:2899
      Definitions:
      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:1186
      Result:true
      Title:Mount Remote Filesystems with nosuid
      Description:The nosuid option should be enabled for all NFS mounts in /etc/fstab.
      Class:compliance
      Tests:
      • true (All child checks must be true.)
        • true (all nfs in /etc/fstab has nosuid)
        • true (all nfs has nosuid)
      Tests:
      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:1188 (textfilecontent54_test)
      Result:true
      Title:all nfs in /etc/fstab has nosuid
      Check Existence:Zero or more collected items may exist.
      Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2930 (textfilecontent54_object)
      Object Requirements:
      • filepath must be equal to '/etc/fstab'
      • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*\[?[\.\w:-]+\]?:[/\w-]+\s+[/\w-]+\s+nfs[4]?\s+(.*)$'
      • instance must not be equal to '0'
      State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:2931 (textfilecontent54_state)
      State Requirements:
      • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must match the pattern '^.*nosuid.*$'
      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:8666900 (textfilecontent54_test)
      Result:true
      Title:all nfs has nosuid
      Check Existence:Zero or more collected items may exist.
      Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:8666900 (textfilecontent54_object)
      Object Requirements:
      • filepath must be equal to '/etc/mtab'
      • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*\[?[\.\w:-]+\]?:[/\w-]+\s+[/\w-]+\s+nfs[4]?\s+(.*)$'
      • instance must not be equal to '0'
      State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:2931 (textfilecontent54_state)
      State Requirements:
      • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must match the pattern '^.*nosuid.*$'

      The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must prevent binary files from being executed on file systems that are being imported via Network File System (NFS).

      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204483r603261_rule
      Result:Pass
      Version:RHEL-07-021021
      Identities:CCE-80436-9
      SV-87813
      V-73161
      CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
      Description: The "noexec" mount option causes the system to not execute binary files. This option must be used for mounting any file system not containing approved binary files as they may be incompatible. Executing files from untrusted file systems increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access. false
      Fix Text:Configure the "/etc/fstab" to use the "noexec" option on file systems that are being imported via NFS.
      Severity:medium
      Weight:10.0
      Reference:
      Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Publisher:DISA
      Type:DPMS Target
      Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Identifier:2899
      Definitions:
      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:1178
      Result:true
      Title:Mount Remote Filesystems with noexec
      Description:The noexec option should be enabled for all NFS mounts in /etc/fstab.
      Class:compliance
      Tests:
      • true (All child checks must be true.)
        • true (all nfs in /etc/fstab has noexec)
        • true (all nfs in /etc/mtab has noexec)
      Tests:
      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:1180 (textfilecontent54_test)
      Result:true
      Title:all nfs in /etc/fstab has noexec
      Check Existence:Zero or more collected items may exist.
      Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2921 (textfilecontent54_object)
      Object Requirements:
      • filepath must be equal to '/etc/fstab'
      • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*\[?[\.\w:-]+\]?:[/\w-]+\s+[/\w-]+\s+nfs[4]?\s+(.*)$'
      • instance must not be equal to '0'
      State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:2922 (textfilecontent54_state)
      State Requirements:
      • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must match the pattern '^.*noexec.*$'
      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:8781300 (textfilecontent54_test)
      Result:true

      Check Existence:Zero or more collected items may exist.
      Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:8781300 (textfilecontent54_object)
      Object Requirements:
      • filepath must be equal to '/etc/mtab'
      • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*\[?[\.\w:-]+\]?:[/\w-]+\s+[/\w-]+\s+nfs[4]?\s+(.*)$'
      • instance must not be equal to '0'
      State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:2922 (textfilecontent54_state)
      State Requirements:
      • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must match the pattern '^.*noexec.*$'

      The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that all world-writable directories are group-owned by root, sys, bin, or an application group.

      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204487r744106_rule
      Result:Error
      Version:RHEL-07-021030
      Identities:CCE-80136-5
      V-72047
      SV-86671
      CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
      Description: If a world-writable directory is not group-owned by root, sys, bin, or an application Group Identifier (GID), unauthorized users may be able to modify files created by others.

      The only authorized public directories are those temporary directories supplied with the system or those designed to be temporary file repositories. The setting is normally reserved for directories used by the system and by users for temporary file storage, (e.g., /tmp), and for directories requiring global read/write access. false
      Fix Text:All directories in local partitions which are world-writable should be group-owned by root or another system account. If any world-writable directories are not group-owned by a system account, this should be investigated. Following this, the directories should be deleted or assigned to an appropriate group.
      Severity:medium
      Weight:10.0
      Reference:
      Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Publisher:DISA
      Type:DPMS Target
      Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Identifier:2899
      Definitions:
      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:1009
      Result:error
      Title:Find world writable directories not group-owned by a system account
      Description:All world writable directories should be group-owned by a system user.
      Class:compliance
      Tests:
      • error (All child checks must be true.) (negated)
        • error (check for local directories that are world writable and have gid greater than or equal to 1000)
      Tests:
      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:1010 (file_test)
      Result:error
      Title:check for local directories that are world writable and have gid greater than or equal to 1000
      Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
      Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2783 (file_object)
      Object Requirements:
      • behavior requirements:
        • recurse = directories
        • recurse_direction = down
        • recurse_file_system = local
      • path must be equal to '/'
      Include Items If:
      • group_id is greater than or equal to '1000'
      • owrite equals 'true'
      State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:2784 (file_state)
      State Requirements:
      • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', group_id must be greater than or equal to '1000'
      • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', owrite must be equal to 'true'
      Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

      The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that the cron.allow file, if it exists, is owned by root.

      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204490r603261_rule
      Result:Pass
      Version:RHEL-07-021110
      Identities:CCE-80378-3
      V-72053
      SV-86677
      CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
      Description: If the owner of the "cron.allow" file is not set to root, the possibility exists for an unauthorized user to view or to edit sensitive information. false
      Fix Text:Set the owner on the "/etc/cron.allow" file to root with the following command:

      # chown root /etc/cron.allow
      Severity:medium
      Weight:10.0
      Reference:
      Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Publisher:DISA
      Type:DPMS Target
      Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7

        • true (Testing user ownership of /etc/cron.allow)

      • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', user_id must be equal to '0'

      The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that the cron.allow file, if it exists, is group-owned by root.

      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204491r603261_rule
      Result:Pass
      Version:RHEL-07-021120
      Identities:CCE-80379-1
      SV-86679

      Description: If the group owner of the "cron.allow" file is not set to root, sensitive information could be viewed or edited by unauthorized users. false

      The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that a separate file system is used for user home directories (such as /home or an equivalent).

      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204493r603840_rule

      Version:RHEL-07-021310
      Identities:CCE-80144-9
      SV-86683
      V-72059

      Description: The use of separate file systems for different paths can protect the system from failures resulting from a file system becoming full or failing. false
      Fix Text:Migrate the "/home" directory onto a separate file system/partition.
      Severity:low
      Weight:10.0
      Reference:

      Publisher:DISA
      Type:DPMS Target
      Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Identifier:2899

      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:1311
      Result:false
      Title:Ensure /home Located On Separate Partition
      Description:If user home directories will be stored locally, create a separate partition for /home. If /home will be mounted from another system such as an NFS server, then creating a separate partition is not necessary at this time, and the mountpoint can instead be configured later.
      Class:compliance

      • false (All child checks must be true.)
        • false (/home on own partition)

      The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must use a separate file system for /var.

      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204494r603261_rule
      Result:Fail
      Version:RHEL-07-021320
      Identities:CCE-26404-4
      V-72061
      SV-86685

      Description: The use of separate file systems for different paths can protect the system from failures resulting from a file system becoming full or failing. false
      Fix Text:Migrate the "/var" path onto a separate file system.
      Severity:low
      Weight:10.0
      Reference:
      Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Publisher:DISA
      Type:DPMS Target
      Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Identifier:2899

      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:1315
      Result:false
      Title:Ensure /var Located On Separate Partition
      Description:Ensuring that /var is mounted on its own partition enables the setting of more restrictive mount options, which is used as temporary storage by many program, particularly system services such as daemons. It is not uncommon for the /var directory to contain world-writable directories, installed by other software packages.
      Class:compliance

      [ not evaluated ]

      The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must use a separate file system for the system audit data path.

      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204495r603261_rule
      Result:Fail
      Version:RHEL-07-021330
      Identities:SV-86687
      V-72063
      CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
      Description: The use of separate file systems for different paths can protect the system from failures resulting from a file system becoming full or failing. false
      Fix Text:Migrate the system audit data path onto a separate file system.
      Severity:low
      Weight:10.0
      Reference:
      Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Publisher:DISA
      Type:DPMS Target
      Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Identifier:2899
      Definitions:
      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:1319
      Result:false
      Title:Ensure /var/log/audit Located On Separate Partition
      Description:Audit logs are stored in the /var/log/audit directory. Ensure that it has its own partition or logical volume. Make absolutely certain that it is large enough to store all audit logs that will be created by the auditing daemon.
      Class:compliance
      Tests:
      • false (All child checks must be true.)
        • false (check for /var/log/audit partition)
        • false (/var/log/audit configured in /etc/fstab)
      Tests:

      The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must use a separate file system for /tmp (or equivalent).

      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204496r603261_rule
      Result:Fail
      Version:RHEL-07-021340
      Identities:CCE-27173-4
      SV-86689
      V-72065
      CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
      Description: The use of separate file systems for different paths can protect the system from failures resulting from a file system becoming full or failing. false
      Fix Text:Start the "tmp.mount" service with the following command:

      # systemctl enable tmp.mount

      OR

      Edit the "/etc/fstab" file and ensure the "/tmp" directory is defined in the fstab with a device and mount point.
      Severity:low
      Weight:10.0
      Reference:
      Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Publisher:DISA
      Type:DPMS Target
      Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Identifier:2899
      Definitions:

      Result:false
      Title:The system must use a separate file system for /tmp (or equivalent).
      Description:The use of separate file systems for different paths can protect the system from failures resulting from a file system becoming full or failing.
      Class:compliance

      • false (All child checks must be true.)
        • false (check for /tmp)

      • mount_point does not exist
      Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

      The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must implement NIST FIPS-validated cryptography for the following: to provision digital signatures, to generate cryptographic hashes, and to protect data requiring data-at-rest protections in accordance with applicable federal laws, Executive Orders, directives, policies, regulations, and standards.

      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204497r603261_rule
      Result:Fail
      Version:RHEL-07-021350
      Identities:CCE-80359-3
      SV-86691
      V-72067
      CCI-000068 (NIST SP 800-53: AC-17 (2); NIST SP 800-53A: AC-17 (2).1; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-17 (2); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-17 (2))
      CCI-001199 (NIST SP 800-53: SC-28; NIST SP 800-53A: SC-28.1; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: SC-28; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: SC-28)
      CCI-002450 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: SC-13; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: SC-13 b)
      CCI-002476 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: SC-28 (1); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: SC-28 (1))
      Description: Use of weak or untested encryption algorithms undermines the purposes of using encryption to protect data. The operating system must implement cryptographic modules adhering to the higher standards approved by the federal government since this provides assurance they have been tested and validated.

      Satisfies: SRG-OS-000033-GPOS-00014, SRG-OS-000185-GPOS-00079, SRG-OS-000396-GPOS-00176, SRG-OS-000405-GPOS-00184, SRG-OS-000478-GPOS-00223 false
      Fix Text:Configure the operating system to implement DoD-approved encryption by installing the dracut-fips package.

      To enable strict FIPS compliance, the fips=1 kernel option needs to be added to the kernel command line during system installation so key generation is done with FIPS-approved algorithms and continuous monitoring tests in place.

      Configure the operating system to implement DoD-approved encryption by following the steps below:

      The fips=1 kernel option needs to be added to the kernel command line during system installation so that key generation is done with FIPS-approved algorithms and continuous monitoring tests in place. Users should also ensure that the system has plenty of entropy during the installation process by moving the mouse around, or if no mouse is available, ensuring that many keystrokes are typed. The recommended amount of keystrokes is 256 and more. Less than 256 keystrokes may generate a non-unique key.

      Install the dracut-fips package with the following command:

      # yum install dracut-fips

      Recreate the "initramfs" file with the following command:

      Note: This command will overwrite the existing "initramfs" file.

      # dracut -f

      Modify the kernel command line of the current kernel in the "grub.cfg" file by adding the following option to the GRUB_CMDLINE_LINUX key in the "/etc/default/grub" file and then rebuild the "grub.cfg" file:

      fips=1

      Changes to "/etc/default/grub" require rebuilding the "grub.cfg" file as follows:

      On BIOS-based machines, use the following command:

      # grub2-mkconfig -o /boot/grub2/grub.cfg

      On UEFI-based machines, use the following command:

      # grub2-mkconfig -o /boot/efi/EFI/redhat/grub.cfg

      If /boot or /boot/efi reside on separate partitions, the kernel parameter boot= must be added to the kernel command line. You can identify a partition by running the df /boot or df /boot/efi command:

      # df /boot
      Filesystem 1K-blocks Used Available Use% Mounted on
      /dev/sda1 495844 53780 416464 12% /boot

      To ensure the "boot=" configuration option will work even if device naming changes occur between boots, identify the universally unique identifier (UUID) of the partition with the following command:

      # blkid /dev/sda1
      /dev/sda1: UUID="05c000f1-a213-759e-c7a2-f11b7424c797" TYPE="ext4"

      For the example above, append the following string to the kernel command line:

      boot=UUID=05c000f1-a213-759e-c7a2-f11b7424c797

      If the file /etc/system-fips does not exists, recreate it:

      # touch /etc/ system-fips

      Reboot the system for the changes to take effect.
      Severity:high
      Weight:10.0
      Reference:
      Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Publisher:DISA
      Type:DPMS Target
      Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Identifier:2899
      Definitions:

      • false (All child checks must be true.)
        • false (One or more child checks must be true.)

        • false (check for fips=1 in grub.cfg)
        • false (check for 1 in /proc/sys/crypto/fips_enabled)
        • true (check for fips=0 in /etc/default/grub)
        • false (/etc/system-fips exists)
        • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (redhat-release-virtualization-host RPM package is installed)
            • false (RHEVH base RHEL is version 7)
          • false (redhat-release-client is version 7)
          • false (redhat-release-workstation is version 7)
          • false (redhat-release-server is version 7)
          • false (redhat-release-computenode is version 7)
        • true (One or more child checks must be true.)
          • false (Tests whether prelinking is disabled)
          • true (All child checks must be true.)
            • true (package prelink is removed)
        • false (All child checks must be true.)
          • false (package dracut-fips is installed)

      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204502r603261_rule
      Result:Pass
      Version:RHEL-07-021710
      Identities:CCE-27165-0
      V-72077
      SV-86701
      CCI-000381 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-7; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-7.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-7 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-7 a)
      Description: It is detrimental for operating systems to provide, or install by default, functionality exceeding requirements or mission objectives. These unnecessary capabilities or services are often overlooked and therefore may remain unsecured. They increase the risk to the platform by providing additional attack vectors.

      Operating systems are capable of providing a wide variety of functions and services. Some of the functions and services, provided by default, may not be necessary to support essential organizational operations (e.g., key missions, functions).

      Examples of non-essential capabilities include, but are not limited to, games, software packages, tools, and demonstration software not related to requirements or providing a wide array of functionality not required for every mission, but which cannot be disabled. false
      Fix Text:Configure the operating system to disable non-essential capabilities by removing the telnet-server package from the system with the following command:

      # yum remove telnet-server
      Severity:high
      Weight:10.0
      Reference:
      Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Publisher:DISA
      Type:DPMS Target

      Check Existence:No collected items may exist.
      Check:Result is based on check existence only.
      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:3007 (rpminfo_object)
      Object Requirements:
      • name must be equal to 'telnet-server'

      The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that auditing is configured to produce records containing information to establish what type of events occurred, where the events occurred, the source of the events, and the outcome of the events. These audit records must also identify individual identities of group account users.

      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204503r603261_rule
      Result:Fail
      Version:RHEL-07-030000
      Identities:CCE-27407-6
      SV-86703
      V-72079
      CCI-000126 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-2 d; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-2.1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-2 d; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-2 c)
      CCI-000131 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-3; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-3.1; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-3; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-3 b)
      Description: Without establishing what type of events occurred, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events leading up to an outage or attack.

      Audit record content that may be necessary to satisfy this requirement includes, for example, time stamps, source and destination addresses, user/process identifiers, event descriptions, success/fail indications, filenames involved, and access control or flow control rules invoked.

      Associating event types with detected events in the operating system audit logs provides a means of investigating an attack; recognizing resource utilization or capacity thresholds; or identifying an improperly configured operating system.

      Satisfies: SRG-OS-000038-GPOS-00016, SRG-OS-000039-GPOS-00017, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00021, SRG-OS-000254-GPOS-00095, SRG-OS-000255-GPOS-00096 false
      Fix Text:Configure the operating system to produce audit records containing information to establish when (date and time) the events occurred.

      Enable the auditd service with the following command:

      # systemctl start auditd.service
      Severity:medium
      Weight:10.0
      Reference:
      Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Publisher:DISA
      Type:DPMS Target

      The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must shut down upon audit processing failure, unless availability is an overriding concern. If availability is a concern, the system must alert the designated staff (System Administrator [SA] and Information System Security Officer [ISSO] at a minimum) in the event of an audit processing failure.

      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204504r603261_rule
      Result:Error
      Version:RHEL-07-030010
      Identities:CCE-80381-7
      V-72081
      SV-86705
      CCI-000139 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-5 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-5.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-5 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-5 a)
      Description: It is critical for the appropriate personnel to be aware if a system is at risk of failing to process audit logs as required. Without this notification, the security personnel may be unaware of an impending failure of the audit capability, and system operation may be adversely affected.

      Audit processing failures include software/hardware errors, failures in the audit capturing mechanisms, and audit storage capacity being reached or exceeded.

      This requirement applies to each audit data storage repository (i.e., distinct information system component where audit records are stored), the centralized audit storage capacity of organizations (i.e., all audit data storage repositories combined), or both.

      Satisfies: SRG-OS-000046-GPOS-00022, SRG-OS-000047-GPOS-00023 false
      Fix Text:Configure the operating system to shut down in the event of an audit processing failure.

      Add or correct the option to shut down the operating system with the following command:

      # auditctl -f 2

      Edit the "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules" file and add the following line:

      -f 2

      If availability has been determined to be more important, and this decision is documented with the ISSO, configure the operating system to notify system administration staff and ISSO staff in the event of an audit processing failure with the following command:

      # auditctl -f 1

      Edit the "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules" file and add the following line:

      -f 1

      Kernel log monitoring must also be configured to properly alert designated staff.

      The audit daemon must be restarted for the changes to take effect.
      Severity:medium
      Weight:10.0
      Reference:
      Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Publisher:DISA
      Type:DPMS Target
      Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Identifier:2899
      Definitions:
      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:776
      Result:error
      Title:Shutdown System When Auditing Failures Occur
      Description:The system will shutdown when auditing fails.
      Class:compliance

        • error (All child checks must be true.)
          • error (audit augenrules configuration shutdown)
          • true (All child checks must be true.)
            • true (audit augenrules)

          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (audit auditctl)

      The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured to off-load audit logs onto a different system or storage media from the system being audited.

      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204506r603261_rule
      Result:Fail
      Version:RHEL-07-030201
      Identities:SV-95729
      V-81017
      CCI-001851 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-4 (1); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-4 (1))
      Description: Information stored in one location is vulnerable to accidental or incidental deletion or alteration.

      Off-loading is a common process in information systems with limited audit storage capacity.

      One method of off-loading audit logs in Red Hat Enterprise Linux is with the use of the audisp-remote dameon. Without the configuration of the "au-remote" plugin, the audisp-remote daemon will not off load the logs from the system being audited.

      Satisfies: SRG-OS-000342-GPOS-00133, SRG-OS-000479-GPOS-00224 false
      Fix Text:Edit the /etc/audisp/plugins.d/au-remote.conf file and add or update the following values:

      direction = out
      path = /sbin/audisp-remote
      type = always

      The audit daemon must be restarted for changes to take effect:

      # service auditd restart
      Severity:medium
      Weight:10.0
      Reference:
      Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Publisher:DISA
      Type:DPMS Target
      Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Identifier:2899
      Definitions:
      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:95729
      Result:false
      Title:The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must configure the au-remote plugin to off-load audit logs using the audisp-remote daemon.
      Description:The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must configure the au-remote plugin to off-load audit logs using the audisp-remote daemon.
      Class:compliance
      Tests:
      • false (All child checks must be true.)
        • false (/etc/audisp/plugins.d/au-remote.conf active = yes)
        • false (/etc/audisp/plugins.d/au-remote.conf direction = out)
        • false (/etc/audisp/plugins.d/au-remote.conf path = /sbin/audisp-remote)
        • false (/etc/audisp/plugins.d/au-remote.conf type = always)
      Tests:

      • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'

      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:9572901 (textfilecontent54_test)

      The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must take appropriate action when the remote logging buffer is full.

      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204507r603261_rule
      Result:Pass
      Version:RHEL-07-030210
      Identities:V-81019
      SV-95731
      CCI-001851 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-4 (1); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-4 (1))
      Description: Information stored in one location is vulnerable to accidental or incidental deletion or alteration.

      Off-loading is a common process in information systems with limited audit storage capacity.

      One method of off-loading audit logs in Red Hat Enterprise Linux is with the use of the audisp-remote dameon. When the remote buffer is full, audit logs will not be collected and sent to the central log server.

      Satisfies: SRG-OS-000342-GPOS-00133, SRG-OS-000479-GPOS-00224 false
      Fix Text:Edit the /etc/audisp/audispd.conf file and add or update the "overflow_action" option:

      overflow_action = syslog

      The audit daemon must be restarted for changes to take effect:

      # service auditd restart
      Severity:medium
      Weight:10.0
      Reference:
      Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Publisher:DISA
      Type:DPMS Target
      Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Identifier:2899
      Definitions:
      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:95731
      Result:true
      Title:The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must take appropriate action when the audisp-remote buffer is full.
      Description:The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must take appropriate action when the audisp-remote buffer is full.
      Class:compliance
      Tests:
      • true (One or more child checks must be true.)
        • true (Check the value assigned to overflow_action in /etc/audisp/audispd.conf)
      Tests:
      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:9573100 (textfilecontent54_test)
      Result:true
      Title:Check the value assigned to overflow_action in /etc/audisp/audispd.conf
      Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
      Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:9573100 (textfilecontent54_object)
      Object Requirements:
      • filepath must be equal to '/etc/audisp/audispd.conf'
      • pattern must match the pattern '(?i)^\s*overflow_action[ ]*=[ ]*([\w]+)\s*'
      • instance must be equal to '1'
      State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:9573100 (textfilecontent54_state)
      State Requirements:
      • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must match the pattern '(?i)^syslog|single|halt$'
      Collected Item/State Result:
      [ true ]
      • filepath equals '/etc/audisp/audispd.conf'
      • path equals '/etc/audisp'
      • filename equals 'audispd.conf'
      • pattern equals '(?i)^\s*overflow_action[ ]*=[ ]*([\w]+)\s*'
      • instance equals '1'
      • text equals 'overflow_action = SYSLOG '
      • line equals 'overflow_action = SYSLOG '
      • subexpression equals 'SYSLOG'

      The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must label all off-loaded audit logs before sending them to the central log server.

      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204508r603261_rule
      Result:Pass
      Version:RHEL-07-030211
      Identities:SV-95733
      V-81021
      CCI-001851 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-4 (1); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-4 (1))
      Description: Information stored in one location is vulnerable to accidental or incidental deletion or alteration.

      Off-loading is a common process in information systems with limited audit storage capacity.

      One method of off-loading audit logs in Red Hat Enterprise Linux is with the use of the audisp-remote dameon. When audit logs are not labeled before they are sent to a central log server, the audit data will not be able to be analyzed and tied back to the correct system.

      Satisfies: SRG-OS-000342-GPOS-00133, SRG-OS-000479-GPOS-00224 false
      Fix Text:Edit the /etc/audisp/audispd.conf file and add or update the "name_format" option:

      name_format = hostname

      The audit daemon must be restarted for changes to take effect:

      # service auditd restart
      Severity:medium
      Weight:10.0
      Reference:
      Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Publisher:DISA
      Type:DPMS Target
      Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Identifier:2899
      Definitions:
      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:95733
      Result:true
      Title:The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must label all off-loaded audit logs before sending them to the central log server.
      Description:The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must label all off-loaded audit logs before sending them to the central log server.
      Class:compliance
      Tests:
      • true (One or more child checks must be true.)
        • true (Check the value assigned to name_format in /etc/audisp/audispd.conf)
      Tests:
      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:9573300 (textfilecontent54_test)
      Result:true
      Title:Check the value assigned to name_format in /etc/audisp/audispd.conf
      Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
      Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:9573300 (textfilecontent54_object)
      Object Requirements:
      • filepath must be equal to '/etc/audisp/audispd.conf'
      • pattern must match the pattern '(?i)^\s*name_format[ ]*=[ ]*([\w]+)\s*'
      • instance must be equal to '1'

      State Requirements:
      • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must match the pattern '(?i)^hostname|fqd|numeric$'

      [ true ]
      • filepath equals '/etc/audisp/audispd.conf'
      • path equals '/etc/audisp'

      The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must off-load audit records onto a different system or media from the system being audited.

      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204509r603261_rule
      Result:Fail
      Version:RHEL-07-030300
      Identities:V-72083
      SV-86707
      CCI-001851 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-4 (1); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-4 (1))
      Description: Information stored in one location is vulnerable to accidental or incidental deletion or alteration.

      Off-loading is a common process in information systems with limited audit storage capacity.

      Satisfies: SRG-OS-000342-GPOS-00133, SRG-OS-000479-GPOS-00224 false
      Fix Text:Configure the operating system to off-load audit records onto a different system or media from the system being audited.

      Set the remote server option in "/etc/audisp/audisp-remote.conf" with the IP address of the log aggregation server.
      Severity:medium
      Weight:10.0
      Reference:

      Publisher:DISA

      Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
      Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:8670700 (textfilecontent54_object)
      Object Requirements:
      • behavior requirements:
        • ignore_case = true
      • filepath must be equal to '/etc/audisp/audisp-remote.conf'
      • pattern must match the pattern '^[ ]*remote_server[ ]+=[ ]+(.*)'
      • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'

      Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

      The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must encrypt the transfer of audit records off-loaded onto a different system or media from the system being audited.

      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204510r603261_rule
      Result:Fail
      Version:RHEL-07-030310
      Identities:V-72085
      SV-86709
      CCI-001851 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-4 (1); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-4 (1))
      Description: Information stored in one location is vulnerable to accidental or incidental deletion or alteration.

      Off-loading is a common process in information systems with limited audit storage capacity.

      Satisfies: SRG-OS-000342-GPOS-00133, SRG-OS-000479-GPOS-00224 false
      Fix Text:Configure the operating system to encrypt the transfer of off-loaded audit records onto a different system or media from the system being audited.

      Uncomment the "enable_krb5" option in "/etc/audisp/audisp-remote.conf" and set it with the following line:

      enable_krb5 = yes
      Severity:medium
      Weight:10.0
      Reference:

      The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that the audit system takes appropriate action when the audit storage volume is full.

      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204511r603261_rule
      Result:Fail
      Version:RHEL-07-030320
      Identities:V-72087
      SV-86711
      CCI-001851 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-4 (1); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-4 (1))
      Description: Taking appropriate action in case of a filled audit storage volume will minimize the possibility of losing audit records.
      One method of off-loading audit logs in Red Hat Enterprise Linux is with the use of the audisp-remote dameon. false
      Fix Text:Configure the action the operating system takes if the disk the audit records are written to becomes full.

      Uncomment or edit the "disk_full_action" option in "/etc/audisp/audisp-remote.conf" and set it to "syslog", "single", or "halt", such as the following line:

      disk_full_action = single
      Severity:medium
      Weight:10.0
      Reference:
      Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Publisher:DISA
      Type:DPMS Target
      Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Identifier:2899
      Definitions:

      • false (All child checks must be true.)

      Tests:

      Result:false

      Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
      State Operator:One or more item-state comparisons may be true.

      Object Requirements:
      • behavior requirements:
        • ignore_case = true
      • filepath must be equal to '/etc/audisp/audisp-remote.conf'
      • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*disk_full_action\s+=\s+(\S+)\s*$'
      • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'

      State Requirements:
      • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must match the pattern '^[Ss][Yy][Ss][Ll][Oo][Gg]$'
      State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:8671101 (textfilecontent54_state)
      State Requirements:
      • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must match the pattern '^[Ss][Ii][Nn][Gg][Ll][Ee]$'
      State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:8671102 (textfilecontent54_state)
      State Requirements:
      • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must match the pattern '^[Hh][Aa][Ll][Tt]$'
      Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

      The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that the audit system takes appropriate action when there is an error sending audit records to a remote system.

      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204512r603261_rule
      Result:Fail
      Version:RHEL-07-030321
      Identities:V-73163
      SV-87815
      CCI-001851 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-4 (1); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-4 (1))
      Description: Taking appropriate action when there is an error sending audit records to a remote system will minimize the possibility of losing audit records.
      One method of off-loading audit logs in Red Hat Enterprise Linux is with the use of the audisp-remote dameon. false
      Fix Text:Configure the action the operating system takes if there is an error sending audit records to a remote system.

      Uncomment the "network_failure_action" option in "/etc/audisp/audisp-remote.conf" and set it to "syslog", "single", or "halt".

      network_failure_action = syslog
      Severity:medium

      The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must immediately notify the System Administrator (SA) and Information System Security Officer (ISSO) (at a minimum) via email when the threshold for the repository maximum audit record storage capacity is reached.

      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204514r603261_rule
      Result:Fail
      Version:RHEL-07-030340
      Identities:V-72091
      SV-86715
      CCI-001855 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-5 (1); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-5 (1))
      Description: If security personnel are not notified immediately when the threshold for the repository maximum audit record storage capacity is reached, they are unable to expand the audit record storage capacity before records are lost. false
      Fix Text:Configure the operating system to immediately notify the SA and ISSO (at a minimum) when the threshold for the repository maximum audit record storage capacity is reached.

      Uncomment or edit the "space_left_action" keyword in "/etc/audit/auditd.conf" and set it to "email".

      space_left_action = email
      Severity:medium
      Weight:10.0
      Reference:

      The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must immediately notify the System Administrator (SA) and Information System Security Officer (ISSO) (at a minimum) when the threshold for the repository maximum audit record storage capacity is reached.

      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204515r603261_rule
      Result:Pass
      Version:RHEL-07-030350
      Identities:CCE-27394-6
      V-72093

      CCI-001855 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-5 (1); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-5 (1))
      Description: If security personnel are not notified immediately when the threshold for the repository maximum audit record storage capacity is reached, they are unable to expand the audit record storage capacity before records are lost. false
      Fix Text:Configure the operating system to immediately notify the SA and ISSO (at a minimum) when the threshold for the repository maximum audit record storage capacity is reached.

      Uncomment or edit the "action_mail_acct" keyword in "/etc/audit/auditd.conf" and set it to root and any other accounts associated with security personnel.

      action_mail_acct = root

      The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must audit all executions of privileged functions.

      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204516r603261_rule
      Result:Error
      Version:RHEL-07-030360
      Identities:V-72095
      SV-86719
      CCI-002234 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-6 (9); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-6 (9))
      Description: Misuse of privileged functions, either intentionally or unintentionally by authorized users, or by unauthorized external entities that have compromised information system accounts, is a serious and ongoing concern and can have significant adverse impacts on organizations. Auditing the use of privileged functions is one way to detect such misuse and identify the risk from insider threats and the advanced persistent threat. false
      Fix Text:Configure the operating system to audit the execution of privileged functions.

      Add or update the following rules in "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules":

      -a always,exit -F arch=b32 -S execve -C uid!=euid -F euid=0 -k setuid
      -a always,exit -F arch=b64 -S execve -C uid!=euid -F euid=0 -k setuid
      -a always,exit -F arch=b32 -S execve -C gid!=egid -F egid=0 -k setgid
      -a always,exit -F arch=b64 -S execve -C gid!=egid -F egid=0 -k setgid

      The audit daemon must be restarted for the changes to take effect.
      Severity:medium
      Weight:10.0
      Reference:
      Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Publisher:DISA
      Type:DPMS Target
      Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Identifier:2899
      Definitions:
      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:710
      Result:error
      Title:The Red Hat EnterpriseLinux Operating system must audit all executions of privileged functions.
      Description:Misuse of privileged functions, either intentionally or unintentionally by authorized users, or by unauthorized external entities that have compromised information system accounts, is a serious and ongoing concern and can have a significant adverse impacts on orginizations. Auditing the use of privileged functions is one way to detect such misuse and identify the risk from insider threats and the advanced persistent threat.
      Class:compliance
      Tests:
      • error (One or more child checks must be true.)
        • error (All child checks must be true.)
          • true (One or more child checks must be true.)
            • error (All child checks must be true.)
              • error (audit augenrules execve uid 64-bit)
              • error (audit augenrules execve gid 64-bit)
            • true (One or more child checks must be true.) (negated)
              • false (All child checks must be true.)
                • false (64 bit architecture)
              • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
                • false (64 bit architecture)
                • false (64 bit architecture)
          • error (audit augenrules execve uid 32-bit)
          • error (audit augenrules execve gid 32-bit)
          • true (All child checks must be true.)
            • true (audit augenrules)
        • false (All child checks must be true.)
          • true (One or more child checks must be true.)
            • false (All child checks must be true.)
              • false (audit auditctl execve uid 64-bit)
              • false (audit auditctl execve gid 64-bit)
            • true (One or more child checks must be true.) (negated)
              • false (All child checks must be true.)
                • false (64 bit architecture)
              • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
                • false (64 bit architecture)
                • false (64 bit architecture)
          • false (audit auditctl execve uid 32-bit)
          • false (audit auditctl execve gid 32-bit)
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (audit auditctl)
      Tests:
      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:8671900 (textfilecontent54_test)
      Result:error
      Title:audit augenrules execve uid 64-bit
      Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
      Check:Result is based on check existence only.
      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:8671900 (textfilecontent54_object)
      Object Requirements:
      • path must be equal to '/etc/audit/rules.d'
      • filename must match the pattern '.*\.rules$'
      • pattern must match the pattern '^\-a\s+always,exit\s+\-F\s+arch=b64\s+\-S\s+execve\s+\-C\s+uid!=euid\s+\-F\s+euid=0\s+(-k[\s]+|-F[\s]+key=)[-\w]+\s*$'
      • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
      Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:8671901 (textfilecontent54_test)
      Result:error
      Title:audit augenrules execve gid 64-bit
      Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
      Check:Result is based on check existence only.
      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:8671901 (textfilecontent54_object)
      Object Requirements:

      • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'

      Object Requirements:
      • filepath must be equal to '/etc/audit/audit.rules'
      • pattern must match the pattern '^\-a\s+always,exit\s+\-F\s+arch=b32\s+\-S\s+execve\s+\-C\s+uid!=euid\s+\-F\s+euid=0\s+(-k[\s]+|-F[\s]+key=)[-\w]+\s*$'
      • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
      Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:714 (textfilecontent54_test)
      Result:false
      Title:audit auditctl execve gid 32-bit
      Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
      Check:Result is based on check existence only.
      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:3744 (textfilecontent54_object)
      Object Requirements:
      • filepath must be equal to '/etc/audit/audit.rules'
      • pattern must match the pattern '^\-a\s+always,exit\s+\-F\s+arch=b32\s+\-S\s+execve\s+\-C\s+gid!=egid\s+\-F\s+egid=0\s+(-k[\s]+|-F[\s]+key=)[-\w]+\s*$'
      • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
      Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:543 (textfilecontent54_test)
      Result:false
      Title:audit auditctl
      Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
      Check:Result is based on check existence only.
      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2426 (textfilecontent54_object)
      Object Requirements:
      • filepath must be equal to '/usr/lib/systemd/system/auditd.service'
      • pattern must match the pattern '^ExecStartPost=\-\/sbin\/auditctl.*$'
      • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
      Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

      The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must audit all uses of the chown, fchown, fchownat, and lchown syscalls.

      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204517r809570_rule
      Result:Error
      Version:RHEL-07-030370
      Identities:CCE-27364-9
      SV-86721
      V-72097
      CCI-000126 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-2 d; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-2.1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-2 d; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-2 c)
      CCI-000172 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 c; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 c; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 c)
      Description: Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

      Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter).

      When a user logs on, the auid is set to the uid of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to -1. The auid representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals 4294967295. The audit system interprets -1, 4294967295, and "unset" in the same way.

      The system call rules are loaded into a matching engine that intercepts each syscall made by all programs on the system. Therefore, it is very important to use syscall rules only when absolutely necessary since these affect performance. The more rules, the bigger the performance hit. The performance can be helped, however, by combining syscalls into one rule whenever possible.

      Satisfies: SRG-OS-000064-GPOS-00033, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000458-GPOS-00203, SRG-OS-000474-GPOS-00219 false
      Fix Text:Add or update the following rule in "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules":

      -a always,exit -F arch=b32 -S chown,fchown,fchownat,lchown -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k perm_mod

      -a always,exit -F arch=b64 -S chown,fchown,fchownat,lchown -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k perm_mod

      The audit daemon must be restarted for the changes to take effect.
      Severity:medium
      Weight:10.0
      Reference:
      Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Publisher:DISA
      Type:DPMS Target
      Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Identifier:2899
      Definitions:
      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:552
      Result:error
      Title:RHEL-07-030370 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must audit all uses of the chown, fchown, fchownat and lchown syscalls.
      Description:Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one. Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). When a user logs on, the auid is set to the uid of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to -1. The auid representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals 4294967295. The audit system interprets -1, 4294967295, and "unset" in the same way. The system call rules are loaded into a matching engine that intercepts each syscall that all programs on the system makes. Therefore, it is very important to only use syscall rules when you have to since these affect performance. The more rules, the bigger the performance hit. You can help the performance, though, by combining syscalls into one rule whenever possible.
      Class:compliance
      Tests:
      • error (One or more child checks must be true.)
        • error (All child checks must be true.)
          • true (One or more child checks must be true.)
            • error (audit augenrules 64-bit chown)
            • error (audit augenrules 64-bit fchown)
            • error (audit augenrules 64-bit fchownat)
            • error (audit augenrules 64-bit lchown)
            • true (One or more child checks must be true.) (negated)
              • false (All child checks must be true.)
                • false (64 bit architecture)
              • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
                • false (64 bit architecture)
                • false (64 bit architecture)
          • error (audit augenrules 32-bit chown)
          • error (audit augenrules 32-bit fchown)
          • error (audit augenrules 32-bit fchownat)
          • error (audit augenrules 32-bit lchown)
          • true (All child checks must be true.)
            • true (audit augenrules)
        • false (All child checks must be true.)
          • true (One or more child checks must be true.)
            • false (audit auditctl 64-bit chown)
            • false (audit auditctl 64-bit fchown)
            • false (audit auditctl 64-bit fchownat)
            • false (audit auditctl 64-bit lchown)
            • true (One or more child checks must be true.) (negated)
              • false (All child checks must be true.)
                • false (64 bit architecture)
              • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
                • false (64 bit architecture)
                • false (64 bit architecture)
          • false (audit auditctl 32-bit chown)
          • false (audit auditctl 32-bit fchown)
          • false (audit auditctl 32-bit fchownat)
          • false (audit auditctl 32-bit lchown)
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (audit auditctl)

      Object Requirements:
      • filepath must be equal to '/etc/audit/audit.rules'
      • pattern must match the pattern '^[\s]*-a[\s]+always,exit[\s]+(?:.*-F[\s]+arch=b32[\s]+)(?:.*(-S[\s]+lchown[\s]+|([\s]+|[,])lchown([\s]+|[,])))(?:.*-F\s+auid>=1000[\s]+)(?:.*-F\s+auid!=(?:4294967295|-1|unset)[\s]+).*(-k[\s]+|-F[\s]+key=)[-\w]+[\s]*$'
      • instance must be equal to '1'
      Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:543 (textfilecontent54_test)
      Result:false
      Title:audit auditctl
      Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
      Check:Result is based on check existence only.
      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2426 (textfilecontent54_object)
      Object Requirements:
      • filepath must be equal to '/usr/lib/systemd/system/auditd.service'
      • pattern must match the pattern '^ExecStartPost=\-\/sbin\/auditctl.*$'
      • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
      Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

      The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must audit all uses of the chmod, fchmod, and fchmodat syscalls.

      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204521r809772_rule
      Result:Error
      Version:RHEL-07-030410
      Identities:CCE-27339-1
      SV-86729
      V-72105
      CCI-000172 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 c; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 c; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 c)
      Description: Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

      Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter).

      When a user logs on, the auid is set to the uid of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to -1. The auid representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals 4294967295. The audit system interprets -1, 4294967295, and "unset" in the same way.

      The system call rules are loaded into a matching engine that intercepts each syscall made by all programs on the system. Therefore, it is very important to use syscall rules only when absolutely necessary since these affect performance. The more rules, the bigger the performance hit. The performance can be helped, however, by combining syscalls into one rule whenever possible.

      Satisfies: SRG-OS-000458-GPOS-00203, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000064-GPOS-00033 false
      Fix Text:Configure the operating system to generate audit records upon successful/unsuccessful attempts to use the "chmod", "fchmod", and "fchmodat" syscalls.

      Add or update the following rules in "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules":

      -a always,exit -F arch=b32 -S chmod,fchmod,fchmodat -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k perm_mod

      -a always,exit -F arch=b64 -S chmod,fchmod,fchmodat -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k perm_mod

      The audit daemon must be restarted for the changes to take effect.
      Severity:medium
      Weight:10.0
      Reference:
      Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Publisher:DISA
      Type:DPMS Target
      Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Identifier:2899
      Definitions:
      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:546
      Result:error
      Title:RHEL-07-030410 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must audit all uses of the chmod, fchmod and fchmodat syscalls.
      Description:Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one. Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). When a user logs on, the auid is set to the uid of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to -1. The auid representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals 4294967295. The audit system interprets -1, 4294967295, and "unset" in the same way. The system call rules are loaded into a matching engine that intercepts each syscall that all programs on the system makes. Therefore, it is very important to only use syscall rules when you have to since these affect performance. The more rules, the bigger the performance hit. You can help the performance, though, by combining syscalls into one rule whenever possible.
      Class:compliance
      Tests:
      • error (One or more child checks must be true.)
        • error (All child checks must be true.)
          • true (One or more child checks must be true.)
            • error (audit augenrules 64-bit chmod)
            • error (audit augenrules 64-bit fchmod)
            • error (audit augenrules 64-bit fchmodat)
            • true (One or more child checks must be true.) (negated)
              • false (All child checks must be true.)
                • false (64 bit architecture)
              • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
                • false (64 bit architecture)
                • false (64 bit architecture)
          • error (audit augenrules 32-bit chmod)
          • error (audit augenrules 32-bit fchmod)
          • error (audit augenrules 32-bit fchmodat)
          • true (All child checks must be true.)
            • true (audit augenrules)
        • false (All child checks must be true.)
          • true (One or more child checks must be true.)
            • false (audit auditctl 64-bit chmod)
            • false (audit auditctl 64-bit fchmod)
            • false (audit auditctl 64-bit fchmodat)
            • true (One or more child checks must be true.) (negated)
              • false (All child checks must be true.)
                • false (64 bit architecture)
              • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
                • false (64 bit architecture)
                • false (64 bit architecture)
          • false (audit auditctl 32-bit chmod)
          • false (audit auditctl 32-bit fchmod)
          • false (audit auditctl 32-bit fchmodat)
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (audit auditctl)
      Tests:
      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:549 (textfilecontent54_test)
      Result:error

      Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
      Check:Result is based on check existence only.
      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2429 (textfilecontent54_object)
      Object Requirements:
      • path must be equal to '/etc/audit/rules.d'
      • filename must match the pattern '.*\.rules$'
      • pattern must match the pattern '^[\s]*-a[\s]+always,exit[\s]+(?:.*-F[\s]+arch=b64[\s]+)(?:.*(-S[\s]+chmod[\s]+|([\s]+|[,])chmod([\s]+|[,])))(?:.*-F\s+auid>=1000[\s]+)(?:.*-F\s+auid!=(?:4294967295|-1|unset)[\s]+).*(-k[\s]+|-F[\s]+key=)[-\w]+[\s]*$'
      • instance must be equal to '1'

      Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

      The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must audit all uses of the setxattr, fsetxattr, lsetxattr, removexattr, fremovexattr, and lremovexattr syscalls.

      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204524r809775_rule
      Result:Error
      Version:RHEL-07-030440
      Identities:CCE-27213-8
      SV-86735
      V-72111
      CCI-000172 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 c; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 c; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 c)
      Description: Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

      Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter).

      When a user logs on, the auid is set to the uid of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to -1. The auid representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals 4294967295. The audit system interprets -1, 4294967295, and "unset" in the same way.

      The system call rules are loaded into a matching engine that intercepts each syscall made by all programs on the system. Therefore, it is very important to use syscall rules only when absolutely necessary since these affect performance. The more rules, the bigger the performance hit. The performance can be helped, however, by combining syscalls into one rule whenever possible.

      Satisfies: SRG-OS-000458-GPOS-00203, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000064-GPOS-00033 false
      Fix Text:Configure the operating system to generate audit records upon successful/unsuccessful attempts to use the "setxattr", "fsetxattr", "lsetxattr", "removexattr", "fremovexattr", and "lremovexattr" syscalls.

      Add or update the following rules in "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules":

      -a always,exit -F arch=b32 -S setxattr,fsetxattr,lsetxattr,removexattr,fremovexattr,lremovexattr -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k perm_mod

      -a always,exit -F arch=b64 -S setxattr,fsetxattr,lsetxattr,removexattr,fremovexattr,lremovexattr -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k perm_mod

      The audit daemon must be restarted for the changes to take effect.
      Severity:medium
      Weight:10.0
      Reference:
      Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Publisher:DISA
      Type:DPMS Target
      Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
      Identifier:2899
      Definitions:
      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:607
      Result:error
      Title:RHEL-07-030440 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must audit all uses of the setxattr, fsetxattr, lsetxattr, removexattr, fremovexattr and lremovexattr syscalls.
      Description:Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one. Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). When a user logs on, the auid is set to the uid of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to -1. The auid representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals 4294967295. The audit system interprets -1, 4294967295, and "unset" in the same way. The system call rules are loaded into a matching engine that intercepts each syscall that all programs on the system makes. Therefore, it is very important to only use syscall rules when you have to since these affect performance. The more rules, the bigger the performance hit. You can help the performance, though, by combining syscalls into one rule whenever possible.
      Class:compliance
      Tests:
      • error (One or more child checks must be true.)
        • error (All child checks must be true.)
          • true (One or more child checks must be true.)
            • error (audit augenrules 64-bit setxattr)
            • error (audit augenrules 64-bit lremovexattr)
            • error (audit augenrules 64-bit lsetxattr)
            • error (audit augenrules 64-bit removexattr)
            • error (audit augenrules 64-bit fremovexattr)
            • error (audit augenrules 64-bit fsetxattr)

      • pattern must match the pattern '^[\s]*-a[\s]+always,exit[\s]+(?:.*-F[\s]+arch=b32[\s]+)(?:.*(-S[\s]+lsetxattr[\s]+|([\s]+|[,])lsetxattr([\s]+|[,])))(?:.*-F\s+auid>=1000[\s]+)(?:.*-F\s+auid!=(?:4294967295|-1|unset)[\s]+).*(-k[\s]+|-F[\s]+key=)[-\w]+[\s]*$'
      • instance must be equal to '1'
      Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:605 (textfilecontent54_test)
      Result:false
      Title:audit auditctl 32-bit removexattr
      Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
      Check:Result is based on check existence only.
      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2474 (textfilecontent54_object)
      Object Requirements:
      • filepath must be equal to '/etc/audit/audit.rules'
      • pattern must match the pattern '^[\s]*-a[\s]+always,exit[\s]+(?:.*-F[\s]+arch=b32[\s]+)(?:.*(-S[\s]+removexattr[\s]+|([\s]+|[,])removexattr([\s]+|[,])))(?:.*-F\s+auid>=1000[\s]+)(?:.*-F\s+auid!=(?:4294967295|-1|unset)[\s]+).*(-k[\s]+|-F[\s]+key=)[-\w]+[\s]*$'
